675537368.name: Must see(when open)
675537368.author: a TripAdvisor user
675537368.reviewBody: I have heard to other reviewers here that the place is under renovation, so apparently people can\'t go in right now. However, when I went in 2010, it was open to the public and absolutely amazing. If it ever opens, I really recommend checking it out.

661349767.name: Not much to see in March 2019
661349767.author: a TripAdvisor user
661349767.reviewBody: As of March 2019 the palace is undergoing renovations and only two small rooms are open.  I was in and out in 5 minutes.  Signs are Spanish-only.

656595033.name: Still closed except for small temporary exhibition
656595033.author: a TripAdvisor user
656595033.reviewBody: Not really worth a visit at current time. Small temporary exhibit of archaeological finds only. Can\'t really appreciate the exterior of the palace either as lots of scaffolding. No date available for reopening.

653591700.name: During Renovation
653591700.author: a TripAdvisor user
653591700.reviewBody: The reconstruction will take more than a year to complete. Unfortunately the Diego Rivera mural is within the reconstruction area and so is unavailable. In the meantime there is a small temporary museum set up within the walls that will feature a series of presentations. At time of writing (February 2019) it\'s about the artistic treatment of animals by the indigenous populations from earliest days. It\'s quite small but well displayed and free. A half hour would be more than enough. Spanish explanations only but most artifacts don\'t need much.

652042292.name: Oldest colonial civil structure in the whole Americas
652042292.author: a TripAdvisor user
652042292.reviewBody: Built in in 1526 it is considered as the oldest colonial civil structure in the whole Americas. It is a Gothic Mudejar fortified building which reminded me of the architecture of western Spain and eastern Portugal. Right in front of it the weekly market was set out, which we decided to tour and look for interesting things.

643874258.name: Closed
643874258.author: a TripAdvisor user
643874258.reviewBody: Closed due to earthquake damage. Mexico City tourist agency had no idea there was no access to O\'Gorman murals. Would have done something else had we known.

641366164.name: Built in 1535
641366164.author: a TripAdvisor user
641366164.reviewBody: Unfortunately closed due to damage from 2017 earthquake. But it is an amazing building. And dominates  the central part of the city.

634469332.name: Impressive
634469332.author: a TripAdvisor user
634469332.reviewBody: This building is impressive and evocative from the outside, but unfortunately it is under renovation since the earthquake and cannot be visited on the inside--so the murals are not visible, sadly.

595637901.name: Que pena que no pudimos entrar
595637901.author: a TripAdvisor user
595637901.reviewBody:
July 2018, 
Local said they just started to renovate the damage that happened by the earthquake in Sep 2017. 

We could not go in. 

Only took some pictures from outside

580003236.name: Would\u2019ve been nice but closed
580003236.author: a TripAdvisor user
580003236.reviewBody: Was hoping it would be open by now 04/2018 but unfortunately it was still under construction due to the earthquake and remain closed. I think if it was open I would\u2019ve enjoy the experience and history. Still looking forward to revisit it one day.

576764640.name: Great and classic
576764640.author: a TripAdvisor user
576764640.reviewBody: One of the oldest and more popular places to be and visit in Cuernavaca, these place is where use to be the government along time to go

564015391.name: Nice &interesting
564015391.author: a TripAdvisor user
564015391.reviewBody: This was a nice place to visit. It is well kept and clean. They have a lot of history to help in understanding the Cortes era.

558001621.name: go to the market
558001621.author: a TripAdvisor user
558001621.reviewBody: don\'t wanna support this colonizer but the market outside was great. look for stalls where they are actually making the artesanias to get the best ones.

551351029.name: Closed due to the earithquake in September 2017
551351029.author: a TripAdvisor user
551351029.reviewBody: Have visited the Palace before but was looking forward to seeing it again after many years. Unfortunately, the recent earthquake damaged the building and it was being repaired during my stay in Cuernavaca,\n

545798496.name: Best Viewed from the Outside
545798496.author: a TripAdvisor user
545798496.reviewBody: Due to the earthquake, quite a bit has changed in Cuernavaca including being able to visit Palacio De Cortex. Best viewed from outside!

544781890.name: Closed
544781890.author: a TripAdvisor user
544781890.reviewBody: Unfortunately closed due to the earthquake damage however the surroundings were pretty fun!  There are tons of vendors that sell everything from jewelry to food items and silver. There\u2019s a large plaza area where you can take lots of photos eat street food like corn, two rows, and other items. Went on a Saturday afternoon and it was very busy.

542641779.name: Earthquake damage
542641779.author: a TripAdvisor user
542641779.reviewBody: You cannot go into the palace or the museum as it is closed due to earthquake damage. The area around the palace is full of shops and stands selling esquites and gifts.

535092966.name: Moctecuzoma\u2019s Summer Palace (Cort\u00e9s Palace)
535092966.author: a TripAdvisor user
535092966.reviewBody: Due to structural damage from the September 19th 2017 earthquake the site is closed to the public. INAH and M\u00e9xico\u2019s Federal engineers are working on accessing damage to make building and grounds accessible to the public.

528802081.name: Solid construction
528802081.author: a TripAdvisor user
528802081.reviewBody: we were in there on the second floor when the 7.1 strength earth quake started.\nApart from the damaged clock tower, some cracks in the wall and big stones that fell down on the street from the outside walls, the place didn\'t collapse and nobody got injured even though I was rather slow to find the exit. If you visit the area, keep the next exit in mind and beware of flimsy looking construction.

511583596.name: "History at its best"
511583596.author: a TripAdvisor user
511583596.reviewBody: The site is full of history (as almost every place or town in Mexico). Travel back many years while you enjoy the multiple colors of Cuernavaca\'s central park which surrounds the Palacio.

510995054.name: Impressive paintigs by Diego Rivera
510995054.author: a TripAdvisor user
510995054.reviewBody: It\'s a very interesting museum were you can see highlighs of the history from prehispanic to the Revoltion.  The paintings by Diego Rivera are awsome and worth enjoying with a guide.

503928944.name: Fascinating
503928944.author: a TripAdvisor user
503928944.reviewBody: Only drawback was all descriptions were in Spanish. Lots of room to roam. Zocalo at front is beautiful and comfortable for people watching.

501650008.name: Nice museum
501650008.author: a TripAdvisor user
501650008.reviewBody: Located in the center of the Zocalo. Very interesting. Great history. The paintings by Diego Rivera were great to see.

501409941.name: Interesting display of how arms and implements of the era
501409941.author: a TripAdvisor user
501409941.reviewBody: you can spend a couple of hours going through the exhibits. It was a Palace where Cortes stayed for some time  and later it was converted into a prison . There is a small market to the right side of the entrance where you can pick up some good bargains

500998396.name: Go for the mural
500998396.author: a TripAdvisor user
500998396.reviewBody: The rain poured down outside the glass as I sat and took in Rivera\'s mural. It\'s very emotional, the suffering of the conquered. The museum is full of very interesting pieces, but the mural is what takes this from 3 star to 5 star. I would say that this is not a museum to visit with small children.

500039029.name: An interesting history spot
500039029.author: a TripAdvisor user
500039029.reviewBody: This place is quite interesting specially by the fact that belonged to the conquer Hern\u00e1n Cortes. The arquitectural style is very impressive. You could visit in 2 hours.

497667370.name: Beautiful
497667370.author: a TripAdvisor user
497667370.reviewBody: Loved this site! The people were friendly the site is clean and all of the artifacts are clearly marked! There are wonderful murals by Diego Rivera on the top floor of the palace. The guides  and docents do not speak English but the concierge does. Takes about two hours to go through but well worth it.

497282539.name: Meh!
497282539.author: a TripAdvisor user
497282539.reviewBody: Decent Mexican History museum, but the building has been renovated so many times in the past 200 years, that you can\'t really tell what it looked like at the time of Cortez.

497030096.name: A museum in a 16th C. palace where lived Hernan Cortes!
497030096.author: a TripAdvisor user
497030096.reviewBody: Besides being an historical residence of the conquistador of Mexico, it has been turned into a museum with an extensive collection of historical artifacts and a 50" mural by Diego Rivera!

487174271.name: Rivera mural is a must see
487174271.author: a TripAdvisor user
487174271.reviewBody: This historic building, made into a museum, is quite interesting in itself, including small looks into excavation of the pyramid it was built atop. The collection of artifacts includes some real gems, prehispanic as well as colonial, but the real star is the mural by Diego Rivera on the top balcony. It depicts the history of the conquest, subjugation and revolution in Cuernavaca in large color over smaller, black and white panels showing the conquest of Mexico City below. I am not that big a fan of Rivera, but this is exceptional.

479659169.name: Excellent visit
479659169.author: a TripAdvisor user
479659169.reviewBody: This is a great collection. Everything is well maintained and it\'s a great history lesson. I learned a great amount about Mexico\'s history and the murals are gorgeous.

475950851.name: Diego Murals were the highlight
475950851.author: a TripAdvisor user
475950851.reviewBody: Nice museum showing the history to Mexico. Nothing in comparison to the Anthropology museum in Mexico City, but does a nice job!

467681135.name: Palacio de Cortes, downtown Cuernavaca
467681135.author: a TripAdvisor user
467681135.reviewBody: This is a huge building, right in downtown Cuernavaca, by one of its two town squares.  There are wonderful murals on some of the walls, and some interesting items.  The most interesting thing to me is the building itself, over 500 years old.

457155201.name: Cortes Palace
457155201.author: a TripAdvisor user
457155201.reviewBody: The Cortes Palace is one of the most important museums in Cuernavaca, it is located in what used to be Corte\'s Palace, when he was stationed here during the conquest of Mexico, this is a must see for any tourist visiting Cuernavaca.

456990103.name: Palacio de Cortes
456990103.author: a TripAdvisor user
456990103.reviewBody: /when you visit here, you will see some very interesting artifacts, some murals by Diego Rivera, and a view of Popocatepetl volcano.\nThere are guides and guide material to help you.

450567316.name: Great museum
450567316.author: a TripAdvisor user
450567316.reviewBody: Spent several hours here. The part on the revolution was great as we see the other statues & art in the museum in Mexico City.  Great murals by Diego Garcia done between 1929 - 1930.  Worth the visit to see those.

448727173.name: Great history in this place
448727173.author: a TripAdvisor user
448727173.reviewBody: The place is good but the surroundings are very dirty , tons of waste , which makes the experience very bad... there is a artisans market next to it, and they sell good products ...

445429866.name: Good for learning about Mexico
445429866.author: a TripAdvisor user
445429866.reviewBody: The museum offers a large retrospective of Mexican history and very impressive mural painting of Mexico notorious painter, Diego Riviera

445027168.name: This is must in that city with the Cathedral.
445027168.author: a TripAdvisor user
445027168.reviewBody: Inside there is the Museo Cuauhnahuac, interesting museum at the former Palacio of Hern\u00e1n Cort\u00e9s. Amazing also with the night lighting.

442985173.name: Hidalgo Cortez and Diego Rivera
442985173.author: a TripAdvisor user
442985173.reviewBody: It had lots of interesting artifacts concerning Cortez, plus Diego Rivera covered the walls and ceilings of an upper floor with frescos depicting the history of Mexico.

440436880.name: When friends visit.....
440436880.author: a TripAdvisor user
440436880.reviewBody: The Palacio is located on the Zocalo in Cuernavaca. When friends come to visit me this is one of the places I always take them. It tells the history  of Cuernavaca and how it became settled. There are also great places to go and have lunch or dinner that are within walking distance from it. Over all a must do when visiting this beautiful city.

439046198.name: Beautiful building; the museum inside is an even better attraction
439046198.author: a TripAdvisor user
439046198.reviewBody: The palace and square are beautiful, impressive, well-kept. The museum within the palace is even better.\n\nLots of vendors, shops, restaurants on the square around the palace; sit and enjoy the world going by, Then take the plunge and go it.

433707012.name: AMAZING MURALS
433707012.author: a TripAdvisor user
433707012.reviewBody: Its been a long time I was there, however, we loved the murals of Diego Rivera, and the exhibit... if you have the chance to go please do.... it is a great experience. right Downtown Cuernavaca.

432479610.name: Fascinating, informative
432479610.author: a TripAdvisor user
432479610.reviewBody: Most of all I enjoyed the photos recording Mexican history...great collection... all sorts of other memorabilia of that time, small and large...

430764149.name: Start here...context and timeline!
430764149.author: a TripAdvisor user
430764149.reviewBody: The castle is filled with archiological, historical, and fine art exhibits that give a clear picture of the pre-columbian past, founding and settlement period, and then the various revolutionary struggles.  When I visited, there was a first rate special exhibition of large prints documenting military struggles - photos printed from large glass plates.  There are objects and machines highlighting the daily life of the community.  The murals of Diego Rivera detailing the conquest are remarkable works, restored the colorful telling of the national story by the master.   Add the views from balconies, galleries, and passages, and one gets an excellent grounding on which to continue exploring the city.

430704166.name: Beautiful
430704166.author: a TripAdvisor user
430704166.reviewBody: Situated in the heart of Cuernavaca right next to a market place. Stunning building both inside and out. Loved visiting here and would highly recommend a visit!

417690761.name: Culture at its best
417690761.author: a TripAdvisor user
417690761.reviewBody: Littered with prehistoric and pre-Hispanic era pieces from mammoth fossils to migration maps, to pottery and stone pieces, this is a must see museum. Next door to an arts and crafts open air market, you can also pick up anything from carefully crafted purse, hats to shot glasses. \n\nThe museum has nineteen halls, which feature a collection of objects from Mexico\'s history. A couple of hours should certainly cover your visit. Everything is in Spanish so ensure you well prepared or you can always request a guide. At 55 pesos (18 pesos to $1) the cost is minor and will leave you with plenty of change to splurge at the marketplace.

405836387.name: Rivera Murals make this very worthwhile.
405836387.author: a TripAdvisor user
405836387.reviewBody: Great insight into local history.  The murals by Diego Rivera are breathtaking and the artifacts very interesting.

401108295.name: Worth a visit
401108295.author: a TripAdvisor user
401108295.reviewBody: Building itself is wonderful. Murals on second floor are stunning. Overall very good. Worth a visit.

396018371.name: Give yourself enough time
396018371.author: a TripAdvisor user
396018371.reviewBody: This museum is beautifully maintained and costs only 55 Pesos to enter (something less than $1.20 when I was here). The layout is brilliant -- as you walk through, you are going through time from the ancient cultures to the Spanish conquistadores to now. \nWe spent hours here; by the time we were done I was exhausted! However, I came with a friend. Had I come with my kids, I think we would have gone through it much faster :)

392929844.name: Interesting
392929844.author: a TripAdvisor user
392929844.reviewBody: It has a lot of pre-Columbian history of the area. It was interesting learning the history of the many uses of the building. Most of the signs are only in Spanish, so my kids were a lost a little interest. The last displays were awesome.  Great Mexican coin collection,  and the Diego Rivera Mural was amazing.

392869773.name: Wonderful place for history buffs
392869773.author: a TripAdvisor user
392869773.reviewBody: We thoroughly enjoyed the Palacio de Cortes.  The museum is very well organized, offering a comprehensive overview of the history of the Mexican state of Morelos and, by extension, a concise history of Mexico.  Indeed, the Diego Rivera murals on the top floor are the biggest attraction but we were also pleased and surprised by the level of knowledge of the museum guards in every room (each devoted to a particular period in Mexican history).  The fact that the original part of the building was constructed in 1526 also makes the visit quite exciting.  I highly recommend the Palacio de Cortes.

392152903.name: Worth the visit
392152903.author: a TripAdvisor user
392152903.reviewBody: Well worth the visit for the Diego Rivera murals alone.  The rest of the museum is a powerful review of Local and Mexican history.  It\'s a must visit.

389885257.name: Pleasant museum in a historic setting
389885257.author: a TripAdvisor user
389885257.reviewBody: Visited the Palacio de Cortes in Cuernavaca recently. It is the former home of Hern\u00e1n Cort\u00e9s, the Conquistador if Mexico. There is a nice collection of Indian artifacts and some exhibits related to Mexican history. A highlight is the mural painted by Diego Rivera. This is a must do in Cuernavaca.

389396013.name: Worth it for the Murals, but little else
389396013.author: a TripAdvisor user
389396013.reviewBody: After a visit here, my suggestion is the Brady Museum in Cuernavaca. An exquisite house and gardens with some great artworks including a Graham Sutherland- Still Life with Bees- Fabulous!

387927855.name: Palacio e Cortes
387927855.author: a TripAdvisor user
387927855.reviewBody: Nice sized museum. Great place to get out of the sun. You can get a discount if you bring your international student ID.

387638030.name: It is a museum and not a palace
387638030.author: a TripAdvisor user
387638030.reviewBody: Average museum only Riveras mural are interesting. It is called a Palace but it was a "civil house" in the time it was built by Cortez.\n

387601841.name: a pleasant interesting surprise
387601841.author: a TripAdvisor user
387601841.reviewBody: this 500 year old facility has exhibitions  dating back many hundreds of years and catalogs events in Mexico before and after the invasion by Spanish soldiers. here you can view examples of ancient stone works as well as a collection of items from the Spanish occupation. go on Sunday as access is free

382810266.name: good place to visit
382810266.author: a TripAdvisor user
382810266.reviewBody: Don\u00b4t go early as few people will be there.  If you  do go early go to the Museo Cuauhnahuac.  Have breakfast in the Placio and watch the people. The place really picks up in the afternoon.

382528061.name: Nice plaza,
382528061.author: a TripAdvisor user
382528061.reviewBody: You can listen to mariachi music during the evenings, of course you can ask them for some songs at a reasonable price.

381744587.name: Such history
381744587.author: a TripAdvisor user
381744587.reviewBody: It has been decades since I studied about the explorers who came from Europe to "the new world".   So this was fascinating to me to read about the Spanish explorers coming to Mexico.   The one thing I never knew was that the Philippines and Mexico started a trade route over 100 years ago.   \n\nThe murals that told such stories of the history were beautiful.   And because I\'m a student studying Spanish in town, I got in free.

379022401.name: Fascinating museum about central Mexico
379022401.author: a TripAdvisor user
379022401.reviewBody: Very well done museum. The staff was very friendly and eager to tell me about the collection and about the history of Morelos.

367567037.name: Palacio de Cortes- Good Museum
367567037.author: a TripAdvisor user
367567037.reviewBody: My husband and I visited the museum on a Sunday. It is free for Mexicans. It is a good place to revisit some of our history. It has beautiful murals, which are worth taking a good look. Pictures are allowed with no flash.

367177799.name: Palacio de Cortez
367177799.author: a TripAdvisor user
367177799.reviewBody: An excellent way to spend a couple of hours learning Mexican history. There\'s a great gift shop and the Rivera murals are exquisite! Not to be missed during a trip to Cuernavaca!!

362384768.name: Love History!!!
362384768.author: a TripAdvisor user
362384768.reviewBody: The location of Cortes Palace it is very interesting, it is downtown Cuernavaca but from this location Hernan Cortes was able to see and control other archeological sites like Teopanzolco, Chipitlan, Tepozteco. and maybe Xochicalco.  Great Museum for the family, lots of things to learn including the beautiful paintings of Diego Rivera.

361006228.name: Lots to see and do
361006228.author: a TripAdvisor user
361006228.reviewBody: This area of Cuernavaca has plenty of good restaurants and shops and the craft market is just next to the museum and is full of great buys. The Zocalo is shaded and lovely for relaxing and watching the local activity. My favorite place to hang out and listen to mariachis practice their music.

360536548.name: A hit in the center of town
360536548.author: a TripAdvisor user
360536548.reviewBody: Beautiful building with some excellent artwork and exhibits. Rivera murals alone are worth a visit. Some exhibits a bit dusty and dry. Some beautiful pre Hispanic pottery and sculptures. Well worth a visit.

357937431.name: Tour of Palicio de Cortes
357937431.author: a TripAdvisor user
357937431.reviewBody: I just completed a tour of this museum.  It is operated by Mexico\'s Instituto Nacional De Antropologia E Historia (INAH) with modern displays of artifacts, paintings, pictures, and historical pieces telling the history of the Morelos region.  The entry fee was only $55Pesos and it was easy to spend a couple hours walking through the two floors of exhibits.  As mentioned by others 95% of the displays are in Spanish only.

353081524.name: Interesting historic building and displays
353081524.author: a TripAdvisor user
353081524.reviewBody: Well worth seeing, from the Olmec\'s pottery (B.C.) to photographs of more modern culture.  Unfortunately very little information is in English, but still intriguing and educational.

351082959.name: Palace of Cortes or Cuauhnahuac Museum is a Must See!
351082959.author: a TripAdvisor user
351082959.reviewBody: The Museo Cuauhnauhuac which is the original name for Cuernavaca is also known as the Palacio de Cortes built after the conquest of 1521 by Hernan Cortes. The museum is well-designed to take the visitor through the history of Cuernavaca from the earliest settlements 3,200 years ago to modern times. The Diego Rivera murals depict the conquest of Cuernavaca by Hernan Cortes and is the highlight of this museum. This is an excellent museum located right in the center of Cuernavaca and is a must for visitors who want to know about the city they are visiting! Great gift and book store run by Fonart adjacent to the museum.

349730211.name: Good tour
349730211.author: a TripAdvisor user
349730211.reviewBody: Following his successful conquest of Mexico, Hernan Cortes could have lived anywhere he wanted. He chose Cuernavaca. Dubious about his popularity among the local people, he built a fortress. Later the building was expanded, and over the years it has served as a city hall, prison, hotel, and museum. Independence leader Jos\u00e9 Maria Morelos y Pav\u00f3n, for whom the state is named, was jailed there right before his execution. The museum includes the oldest clock in America and interesting items from colonial Philipenes. There is 16th century armor, and the murals by Diego Rivera, which tell the history of Cuernavaca, are extraordinary. The official name of the museum is Museo Cauhauhnauc, which is the original name of Cuernavaca. There\'s a small bookstrore next door, and the best place to buy silver and souvenirs is on the square to the south.

349298408.name: Excellent Museum
349298408.author: a TripAdvisor user
349298408.reviewBody: $55 Peso admittance is worth the experience.  The flow through the museum rooms is well designed with nice breaks for city views.  The artifacts are excellent.  Unfortunately many of the descriptions are in Spanish only but some English at the start of many of the 11 rooms helped.  It is a fine opportunity to learn some history of the pre and post Spanish eras of Morelos and Mexico.  Well worth an hour or two.

346668686.name: Exquisite historical site.
346668686.author: a TripAdvisor user
346668686.reviewBody: This is a very interesting palace or castle.  There are historical artifacts, murals by Diego Rivera and many displays that add to one\'s knowledge of Cuernavaca\'s history.

346371627.name: Historical Monument you don\'t want to miss.
346371627.author: a TripAdvisor user
346371627.reviewBody: Spent an afternoon here and was pleasantly surprised, after touring all through the Palace, admiring the historical events, pictures, and artifacts...the best was saved for last....Diego Rivera\'s murals.....WOW.

345051262.name: History of local people and spanish conquest
345051262.author: a TripAdvisor user
345051262.reviewBody: I spent 1 hour. Only 55 pesos to enter. Beautiful murals. Interesting architecture. A must see if you are in Cuernavaca. Next to the zocalo. Try some juice.

344834278.name: Nice museum
344834278.author: a TripAdvisor user
344834278.reviewBody: A good place to learn and remember a some facts about Mexico\'s history.\nI takes about an hour and a half to visit this place.

344736045.name: We really enjoyed this Archaeological Museum
344736045.author: a TripAdvisor user
344736045.reviewBody: This is really surprise. We truly enjoyed going through this museum and would recommend it to any one visiting Cuernavaca.

343190971.name: Well done!
343190971.author: a TripAdvisor user
343190971.reviewBody: I always feel a bit ignorant since I don\'t know the language and wish I either had a guide or there were more English explanations.  Very provincial on my part.

341450125.name: Splendor of the conquistadores!
341450125.author: a TripAdvisor user
341450125.reviewBody: You can only imagine what a sight this palace was at its\' zenith.  The highlight are the Diego Rivera murals, and the fantastic view of the Popocatepetl Volcano on a clear day.

341016057.name: Interesting building
341016057.author: a TripAdvisor user
341016057.reviewBody: A lot of history. Theres a skeleton at the entrance . pretty cool thing to see. This place makes me think how cool it was that hernan cortes chose Cuernavaca to live in.

334131489.name: The Palace of Cortes, Cuernavaca, Mexico
334131489.author: a TripAdvisor user
334131489.reviewBody: This is the one of the oldest civil buildings of its kind in Mexico. It is in easy walking distance of the Cathedral, and has been the Institute Nacional de Anthropologica E Historia since 1974. It was built on the orders of Herman Cortes during the time of the knights satred in 1531 and completed in 1535. It has had a varied history -see Wikipedia- and is particularily notable for the Murals by Diego Rivera painted in 1929 and 1930 depicting the  various stages of Mexican history. Well worth a visit

332310962.name: A real treasure!
332310962.author: a TripAdvisor user
332310962.reviewBody: Went to see the Diego Rivera mural and enjoyed the numerous other items displayed. it traces the history of the region involving the evolution of indigenous people to the many conquests. Even though most plagues were only in Spanish, I found this two story museum fascinating and enjoyable. The size is manageable and the view over the zocalo is lovely. I would highly recommend

325358191.name: Diego Rivera Mural is a Must-see
325358191.author: a TripAdvisor user
325358191.reviewBody: It was a beautiful day, so I was not patient enough to appreciate the interior exhibits (tho I did catch a fascinating bit about how Mexico was HQ for the Catholic push into Asia). However, the Diego Rivera mural is a must. Beautiful work of art, and so interesting to contemplate in today\'s political climate.

314878783.name: Comfort and convenience
314878783.author: a TripAdvisor user
314878783.reviewBody: Despite being five centuries old, this old residence that belonged to Hern\u00e1n Cort\u00e9s --the Spanish conqueror of Mexico and Central America, has been well kept and brought up to date frequently, plus it is right in the middle of the City of Cuernavaca, which allows to enjoy the ever-spring climate that prevails there.

314543155.name: Beautiful art work
314543155.author: a TripAdvisor user
314543155.reviewBody: Awesome little museum I like the fact that it was very informative, as you walk through, they take you through the different periods up to Cortez. There\'s a lot of beautiful artwork, tools, pots & jewelry on display through all the galleries. While we were there a school was having a field trip to the museum to learn about the history and culture.

300497201.name: Hernan Cortez lived very well
300497201.author: a TripAdvisor user
300497201.reviewBody: This man lived better than a King. He lacked nothing and this was in the 1500\'s. It was in the new world when this was created. Wonderful history and beautiful.\n

291824966.name: Very educational
291824966.author: a TripAdvisor user
291824966.reviewBody: Very educational lots of history and artifacts. Foundation of original myan temple cand be seen in parts as all churches and federal buildings were built on top of temples as a way of erasing the myan history

286516908.name: Pick up a good day to stroll outside the building, on the patios.
286516908.author: a TripAdvisor user
286516908.reviewBody: If you like art, especially murals, and architecture, you cannot miss the Palacio de Cortes. You will find exquisite and large murals that cover huge walls painted by the famous Mexican artist Diego Rivera. The dynamic of the figures, the colors, the expressions are magnificent. Subjects are generally social, historical and political. The history of Mexico is depicted on those walls.

273873327.name: Lots to see
273873327.author: a TripAdvisor user
273873327.reviewBody: This museum has lots to see and experience. The building itself is half the attraction, as it has been well preserved and utilized. Absolutely great!

272855265.name: Lots of history!
272855265.author: a TripAdvisor user
272855265.reviewBody: From the remains of an ancient pyramid to the leather outfit worn by a gaucho, there\'s a lot of history here. Unfortunately, only half of the exhibits are explained in English, so I could only deduce what some of the stuff was. But the piece de resistance was the mural by Diego Rivera. Beautiful!

272599995.name: A very good lesson of history
272599995.author: a TripAdvisor user
272599995.reviewBody: The museum is located near the Zocalo (central place). The building itself is a piece of work (ancient palace and 1st civil building in latinamerica). The museum retraces the prehispanic history of the area (ground floor rooms) and the conquista in the first floor. Very interesting museum.\n

271756858.name: Cuernavaca treasure with Diego Rivera Murals.
271756858.author: a TripAdvisor user
271756858.reviewBody: Very good Museum. The exhibits are well displayed with excellent descriptions in English. For us the highlight was the Diego Rivera murals, illustrating Mexican history, both pre and post Cortez days. This is a must visit museum, just for the Rivera murals, which are a world treasure. Nice view of the City from the upstairs.

268112632.name: Definitely worth a visit
268112632.author: a TripAdvisor user
268112632.reviewBody: The main attraction is the building itself. If you are a history buff, it\'s thrilling to walk around a building that dates back to the 1550s and belonged to Hern\u00e1n Cort\u00e9s. Regardless of what you think about the man\'s role in the conquest of Mexico, it\'s interesting to see how the Spanish lived in the 16th century, and how this place functioned as a fortress when they were conquering the surrounding area.  Mexico doesn\'t glorify Cort\u00e9s or the Spanish in general, but it does recognize the importance of their architecture, so the government turned this fantastic building into a regional history museum. Many of the exhibits deal with the pre-colombian civilizations that inhabited the area, but there are also some interesting displays from the colonial period and 19th century.  The murals by Diego Rivera are fascinating.  The museum isn\'t large and won\'t take more than an hour to see, even if you go at a very leisurely pace. It makes a nice break in the day to go inside the museum and get out of the sun and noise of downtown Cuernavaca. Closed on Monday, like all museums in Mexico. Centrally located, right across from the z\u00f3calo. Check out the craft market next to the palace, it\'s a good place to buy souvenirs. The bookstore next door to the museum is also excellent, best selection of books in Cuernavaca (almost all in Spanish).

265921061.name: A monument itself, the museum is the oldest non-military novo-hispanic structure in Mexico
265921061.author: a TripAdvisor user
265921061.reviewBody: Built in 1535 by Hernan Cort\u00e9s, the palace is one of the oldest European-style, civil constructions in the Americas, but is executed in Renaissance style. The series of arches of the central terrace, the battlements, and the thick walls are the most representative aspects of the original construction. It is said that this residence looks much like the mansion built in Santo Domingo by Diego Col\u00f3n, the son of Christopher Columbus. Just outside the front of the building is an old pyramid base over which Cort\u00e9s had the structure built, on a hill that dominated the old city. Petroglyphs recovered from the site and from throughout the city are on display. From right to left the petroglyphs are named Lagarto de San Ant\u00f3n, Aguila de Chapultepec, Piedra Chimalli, or Piedra de los Encantos. After having been the residence of Cort\u00e9s and his descendents for several centuries, the building became a warehouse, a jail, a military barracks, and then the State Government Palace (until 1969). From 1971 to 1973, the building was restored extensively and today houses the Museo Regional Cuauhn\u00e1huac, dedicated to the history of Morelos State. It often is referred to as, the Palacio de Cort\u00e9s. It has ten exhibit halls with maps, illustrations, photographs, works of art, and everyday items from various epochs representing the first human settlements in the state to the present day. It has murals created by Diego Rivera that reflect both Morelos and Mexican history.  Adjacent to the Palacio a permanent local handicraft market in which one may purchase silver jewelry, T-shirts, beaded bracelets, pottery, hammocks, blankets, and much more.\n\nMuseum hours are Tues-Sun 9 \u2013 6. Admission is $41 pesos, free Sundays!

264650365.name: Diego Rivera murals
264650365.author: a TripAdvisor user
264650365.reviewBody: I adore Diego Rivera\'s murals and can sit and look at them for a very long time.  The Palacio has several rooms with museum-type artifacts, but, for me the Diego Rivera murals are the highlight.

263348217.name: Love the Murals
263348217.author: a TripAdvisor user
263348217.reviewBody: Is a must see, is right there in the middle of the city, it was build by the request of Hernan Cortes, the conqueror of Mexico, and later was use by Maximiliano. Today is a museum and has beautiful Murals painted by Diego Rivera, which I love because it describes the history of Mexico.

261636673.name: Dream Come True!
261636673.author: a TripAdvisor user
261636673.reviewBody: I have always been a huge fan of Diego Rivera and the fact that his artwork is displayed in this museum is amazing.  It was always a dream of mine to visit this historical site and it was definitely worth the trip.  The palace has been beautifully preserved and the artifacts are extremely interesting.  We chose to pay a tour guide to walk us through the museum and she was very knowledgeable.  The extra bits of information made the tour much better.  The best part were the Diego Rivera murals that are on the second level.  I loved it!

258782886.name: Nicely put together Museo in a great building
258782886.author: a TripAdvisor user
258782886.reviewBody: Definitely worth an hour or two for a visit if you are in Centro. Lots of interesting things to see from the history of the area. Most of the signs are in Spanish but one main one in each room has English as well. The building is great and there is a room detailing the additions and renovations over the years. In various parts you can see where previous parts of the building stood. The mural by Diego Rivera on the second floor is lovely as well.

256059770.name: Good museum
256059770.author: a TripAdvisor user
256059770.reviewBody: Museum has a great collection of colonial artifacts. Worth admission and an hour or two of your time. The Rivera mall they have on the second floor is beautiful.

255441794.name: Don\'t miss this piece of ancient history
255441794.author: a TripAdvisor user
255441794.reviewBody: This site is over 500 years old and features a wonderful Diego Rivera mural near the entrance.  There are some stairs and bathrooms are on the outside.  No designated parking area since it is right in the Zocalo, so I always take a cab or bus to not worry about parking.  After you are there, so many other places close to explore as well.

246407964.name: Excellent history lesson in Cuernavaca
246407964.author: a TripAdvisor user
246407964.reviewBody: In the center of Cuernavaca, this is a must visit. The palace architecture, the exhibits, and the educational value are all very great. A wonderful place to learn about the history of Mexico and the local area. The attached book store is one of the better examples of its kind.

243829880.name: A Must-see if you visit Cuernavaca
243829880.author: a TripAdvisor user
243829880.reviewBody: Right at the Zocalo, close to a craft market, wonderful way to learn about local and Mexican history.  It brings the culture to life.

241984347.name: A classic
241984347.author: a TripAdvisor user
241984347.reviewBody: Palacio de Cortes is a must.  I have been there for either art, exhibitions or many cultural events.  You can smell live history here, the echo is quite impressive and so is the entire venue.\n

238296531.name: Beautiful Architecture!
238296531.author: a TripAdvisor user
238296531.reviewBody: Lovely and quaint hotel, beautiful grounds. Impeccable customer service. They were setting up for a wedding, and it was gorgeous. The gardens were beautiful, cascading flowers everywhere. Smiling and courteous Mexicans always ready to lend a helping hand. I would definitely go back.

238058862.name: Rivera Mural in Cuernavaca
238058862.author: a TripAdvisor user
238058862.reviewBody: The Museum has permanent exhibits on the history of Cuernavaca - pre-hispanic, the colonial period, up through the Revolution in 1910 and more. There are also frequent temporary exhibits. The prize for me is the Diego Rivera Mural on the back corridor on the second floor. It portrays the conquest of Cuernavaca in vivid detail. I highly recommend the explanation of the mural given by Charlie Goff at the Cemanahuac language school. He points out a lot of interesting historical details.\nThere is a small fee to enter, but if you are a student or senior you may get a discount. The view from the terrace overlooking the zocalo is wonderful. On the back terrace where the mural is you can see the Popocatepetl volcano on a clear day.\nBe sure to check out the book shop that is to the left of the main entrance.

235091179.name: Cuernavaca\'s Best Attraction
235091179.author: a TripAdvisor user
235091179.reviewBody:
Originally built as the palace of Hernán Cortés, this beautiful structure has been carefully tended to over five centuries and is an excellent site to visit. From the large collection of Diego Rivera Murals, to the many one-of-a-kind artifacts on exhibit.

I suggest that you have one of the tour guides to escort you through the many rooms and explain the significance of the objects. You will learn much about the history of the ancient Tenochtitlan, who were the first settlers in the area.

You will learn about what life was like at the time and the culture, up until the Spanish conquest, when Cortes arrived in Mexico from Spain to acquire the gold and silver for the Spanish Crown. 

Cortés tortured Cuauhtemoc, took away their religion and forced them to adapt to another, forever changed their culture and language. The Spaniards forceably took the land, enslaving the Tenochtitlan and put many to work building churches.

There are also exhibits concerning the revolution, the beginning of the industrial age. There is also a large coin collection to see and much more.

On the covered exterior rear patio, you will find the Diego Rivera murals. Look closely at the central figure which many that are not familiar with Diego's work, mistake for Morelos. While the figure is dressed as Morelos might have at the time, the face is a self-portrait of Diego Rivera.

Just out the front door and to your right as you exit, there is a very nice book store that has some very nice souvenirs that are better than what is sold in the foyer of the museum.

233344849.name: A good memory ...
233344849.author: a TripAdvisor user
233344849.reviewBody: I remembered this place which I visited a few years back when in Cuernavaca at a wedding this month.\n\nThe grounds are well-kept and the place is of great historical value from the days of colonization.

232544934.name: Unbelievable value
232544934.author: a TripAdvisor user
232544934.reviewBody: This is one of the oldest structures that remains from the colony days.  The paintings and older artifacts are truly unique.  It is much easier to cover than other museums (de arqueologia, castillo de chapultepec) and a good value if you have kids.  There is a back terrace which looks over the valley that is worth some pictures (the valley is populated with small houses)\n\nGreat if you are looking for something to do with the kids.  Have lunch at Casa Hidalgo across the street (ask for a table in the upstairs terrace, the view is incredible).  Get the carne asada there....good grub

229442276.name: An interesting museum in which you can know more about the colonization.
229442276.author: a TripAdvisor user
229442276.reviewBody:
This museum was Hernan Cortes' house. Now is a beautiful museum that tell us the history of the ancient Tenochtitlan, how they lived, their Gods, their culture; passing through the Spanish conquest, when Cortes came to Mexico and he tortured Cuauhtemoc in order to get  the gold; and the subsequent years, when the spanish brought their religion, their culture and their language, when they stripped the natives of their lands and made them work as slaves to build churches. Then we see a little about the revolution, how Mexico started to be an industrialized country, we can see photos of the Cuernavaca train opening; the evolving of the monetary system (the different coins used during history) and more.

What I liked most was the mural of Diego Rivera, Diego is one of the most important Mexican muralists, and we appreciate his talent at this amazing mural, which tells the colonization and revolution history that we could know in deep in the journey through the different rooms of the museum .

This visit is mandatory!!

227931554.name: A Must See while in Cuernavaca, Mx
227931554.author: a TripAdvisor user
227931554.reviewBody: El Palacio de Cortes is easy to get to as it sits right in El Centro, the center of Cuernavaca.  Believer it or not, McDonald\'s Restaurant is approximately 500 ft from the property in case you get a culture shock and need a quick burger from the States.  This is a great museum, and you will find yourself steeped in Mexican history!  You can find souvenir\'s to take back with you as you enjoy the story of how Cortes came to live in Cuernavaca!  Be sure to go all the way to the front of the building where there is a front veranda and see the much envied views that this palace offers.

227006032.name: Incredible piece of history.
227006032.author: a TripAdvisor user
227006032.reviewBody: Amazing architecture for a structure that is 400 years old. Interesting exhibits in different rooms show the progression of technology in Mexico. Wish the signs had been bi-lingual.

226317759.name: Very interesting but crowds of perople when I was there.
226317759.author: a TripAdvisor user
226317759.reviewBody: Rivera\'s murals are excellent and seem to talk to you. Mexico\'s history shown in chronological order as you go through the different rooms. Unfortunatelly, there were crowds of people when I visited.

226168490.name: Historic place in town
226168490.author: a TripAdvisor user
226168490.reviewBody: Good option to get a view of the history of Mexico. Not so impressive as it could be as it lack of  information, as Mexico is a so rich archeological history....and besides it name it don\'t have any information about Hernan Cortes!,

222379799.name: Beautiful, historic palace!
222379799.author: a TripAdvisor user
222379799.reviewBody: Beautiful and historic palace in the center of Cuernavaca. A must see in Cuernavaca near the Zocalo, walkable around the center of the city.

221279445.name: Super interesting and nice
221279445.author: a TripAdvisor user
221279445.reviewBody: definitely one of the main attration to do in Cuernavaca not to be missed the Diego Rivera Murales on the second floor \n

219461785.name: worth the time
219461785.author: a TripAdvisor user
219461785.reviewBody: I would certainly recommend this place because it is the oldest secular structure in the Americas. The history of the building and its role in the city is explained very well. The mural upstairs is very impressive, although slightly smaller than the usual murals by Rivera. Also, they have some remarkable archeological artifacts which add to your knowledge about the nearby ruins of Xochicalco. All well explained, with some explanations also in English.

219094672.name: Worth the visit to see the murals
219094672.author: a TripAdvisor user
219094672.reviewBody: A partially enclosed veranda on one side of the building has a major Diego Rivera mural, which is worth the visit to Cuernavca. The rest of the museum has many interesting items and is quite informative, but the murals are the highlight.

214878677.name: everything about the palacio is beautiful
214878677.author: a TripAdvisor user
214878677.reviewBody: dont miss the palacio when in cuernavaca, its right in the zocalo, very easy to find. the museum inside is great lots of historical items, dont forget to use your student or teacher id for a discount. diego riveras painting on the wall is incredible. read up on it before your visit. i wish they had a guide in english though! when done there is a nice gift shop, but the market outside has the same items for half the price!

212881727.name: Great starting place
212881727.author: a TripAdvisor user
212881727.reviewBody: First, it\'s right on the main square, the Zocalo, so if you\'re getting acquainted with the city you\'re probably starting here anyway. Next, it\'s loaded with artifacts and history from the area. And finally, if you\'re a Diego Rivera fan you must, must, must see the murals that show local history. If you\'re not already a Diego Rivera fan, you should be.

203667182.name: Gorgeous Palace
203667182.author: a TripAdvisor user
203667182.reviewBody: Unfortunately it was closed since I arrived late in the day, but it was gorgeous on the outside and I can only assume the inside is the same. Also it is right next to the Zocalo which is of course a fun place at night.

198445862.name: Beautiful Area
198445862.author: a TripAdvisor user
198445862.reviewBody: This is an impressive building. It dominates the area in which it resides. Close to the Zocolo, and other great areas of the city. Holds history as well, with Cortes being one of the primary conquistadors who came to Mexico. Worth the time to go and visit.

193290506.name: Beautiful building with wonderful history of the area
193290506.author: a TripAdvisor user
193290506.reviewBody: We were pleasantly surprised by this place.  It is really more of a museum than a palace but the artifacts and exhibits are fascinating  They have large signs in English with details of what\'s in each room so that helps as all the labels on the art work are in Spanish.  If for no other reason, the Diego Rivera mural is worth the trip!

181150006.name: Fun and interesting
181150006.author: a TripAdvisor user
181150006.reviewBody: wonderful mosaics by Diego Rivera; very helpful staff for this mostly non-Spanish speaker; great informal cafe a few doors down the street where you can sit for hours and watch people go by on the plaza.

178075423.name: very good history review of mexico
178075423.author: a TripAdvisor user
178075423.reviewBody: don\'t miss the Diego Rivera painting, i\'ts also for kids, if u have a teacher\'s credential - it helps for discuont

176248439.name: 400 years of mexican history in one place
176248439.author: a TripAdvisor user
176248439.reviewBody: The Cortes\u00b4Palace in downtown Cuernavaca is a majestic site that transfers you into the ancient mexican past when Tenochtitlan, capital of the aztec empire was twice as big as the largest european city, Seville, and the new world was transformed into a new nation. After admiring the collection, just walk across the street for a wonderful lunch/dinner at Casa Hidalgo in central square.

175118102.name: A must visit
175118102.author: a TripAdvisor user
175118102.reviewBody: A very impressive collection and telling of the history of the city and state. Most of the smaller signs are not in English but the main ones are with enough to enjoy the displays. The 46 peso entrance fee is well worth it. It\'s worth the entrance even if you only go to see the Rivera mural - simply very impressive! The rooms are well laid out with plenty of seating to take a break and look out over the centro.

168486440.name: Ok
168486440.author: a TripAdvisor user
168486440.reviewBody: I liked the amazing things they have exposed and Diego Rivera murals are stunning. You could visit this place if you feel like....

162307056.name: Very interesting and complete
162307056.author: a TripAdvisor user
162307056.reviewBody: The collection includes from prehispanic pieces and mastodon fossil to Diego Rivera murals and mexican revolution history also local history. Emiliano Zapata born in Morelos has a complete area of his history in this museum.\n\nFree entrance and very nice museum, easy to locate it\'s and old Castle.

160016084.name: Ok, skip the guide.
160016084.author: a TripAdvisor user
160016084.reviewBody: We booked this as a tour through Best Day.  While most of the tour was decent, the guide spent too much time talking about the artifacts in the Palacio and was difficult to understand.  I\'d recommend skipping a guided tour and viewing the artifacts.  This is more of a museum vs. a collection of things from the Palace.

157219231.name: history of mexico
157219231.author: a TripAdvisor user
157219231.reviewBody: In Cortez\'s palace, a museum of the history of Mexico, especially the state of Morelos, with artifacts, costumes, archeological findings.  Needs a couple of visits. Also fabulous Diego Rivera mural on top floor.

152219881.name: A great museum
152219881.author: a TripAdvisor user
152219881.reviewBody: It is right on the Z\u00f3calo with many great things inside, a very pleasant museum showing Mexican life throughout the centuries.

151456749.name: Surprisingly interesting!
151456749.author: a TripAdvisor user
151456749.reviewBody: Thought this would be a bit of a snooze after spending an entire day in the Archaelogical Musuem in Chapultepec Park in Mexico City but is was surprisingly diverting and worth a look

150863263.name: Cortes and Rivera under one roof
150863263.author: a TripAdvisor user
150863263.reviewBody:
Just spent the afternoon exploring the Cortes Palace.  Really well done museum with lots of artifacts, lots of paintings, lots of insight into the life and history of Cuernavaca.  Added bonus was the complete wing with murals painted by Diego Rivera.  Most of the descriptions however are written in Spanish.

Beautiful vista's from the balconies of the palace of the rest of Cuernavaca so bring your camera.

There is a series of booth's to buy trinkets and other items sold by locals near the museum entrance and the central park across the way also has options for buying local foods and for just relaxing in a local environment.

Bathrooms were on site and they were very clean.  Lots of stairs however and I did not look for an elevator so I do not know if there is one on site.

148548560.name: Worth checking out
148548560.author: a TripAdvisor user
148548560.reviewBody: Would have enjoyed more, if there had been more in English and possibly even a tape explaining things as one walked around.

146614793.name: an affordable cultural visit
146614793.author: a TripAdvisor user
146614793.reviewBody: If you like to spend 2 to 3 hours on a cultural visit when you travel to cities, Palacio de cortes is your choice in Cuernavaca.  Situated in the historical area of the city, within walking distance from the Arts and crafts market, you will be impressed by diego River\'a mural.

146382297.name: if you like big museums, the Palacio de Cort\u00e9s
146382297.author: a TripAdvisor user
146382297.reviewBody: i find museums this big too much to take in, too sober, too many labels to read, too many frankly mute objects.\n\nand the Diego Rivera mural is incredibly powerful.

145902690.name: Diego Rivera Mural
145902690.author: a TripAdvisor user
145902690.reviewBody: This museum boasts a great mural by the artist Diego Rivera, contemperary of Frida Kahlo. The mural is a story and an English speaking guide will help you to identify each section. In the museum there are also several other displays covering Xochicalco, the Mexican Revolution and period of time when sugar was produced in great quantities in this area.

144397067.name: An important piece of history
144397067.author: a TripAdvisor user
144397067.reviewBody: With a guide you will learn of the influences of Diego Rivera and muralism, how Mariachis evolved, how Spanish culture mixed with indigenous culture, the Palace is built on top of a pyramid, and how Christianity influenced Mexico. Second visit and worthwhile.

138794461.name: What a palace!
138794461.author: a TripAdvisor user
138794461.reviewBody: I was lucky enough to have an English speaking guide who spotted us right away.  He has studied the history of Cortes for over 20 years, and he knew his stuff.  You really should have a guide if you don\'t know the history, because you might not realize what you are looking at and what\'s behind having it in the museum.  It took us about an hour and a half with our guide, and it really was a great tour.

136847460.name: Wow!
136847460.author: a TripAdvisor user
136847460.reviewBody: I went here with my family and it was so nice! The staff were friendly and there were tours etc. Recommend it when visiting Cuernavaca!

131019260.name: Great
131019260.author: a TripAdvisor user
131019260.reviewBody: Well worth it, for the spectacular Diego Rivera mural, if nothing else!  The building is very interesting also.  Very sparse information in English, though.

130971218.name: Interesting location
130971218.author: a TripAdvisor user
130971218.reviewBody: Interesting museum in Cuernavaca, and offers some insight in the conquest of Mexico

129481812.name: Rivera\'s mural worth seeing
129481812.author: a TripAdvisor user
129481812.reviewBody: Good place to get some background on Morelia. Rivera\'s mural is sad and moving and inspiring, See the oldest clock (the works from a cathedral) in Latin America. The view is good; one can see why Cortez chose this spot for his weekend home.

128193942.name: nice!
128193942.author: a TripAdvisor user
128193942.reviewBody: Took Alfredo up on his tour offer and it was well worth it.  The Palacio is beautiful and there are many good exhibits but few are in English so his narrative really brought it all together.  I was having lots of flashbacks of 5th grade history.

126586790.name: Cuernavaca & Diego Rivera
126586790.author: a TripAdvisor user
126586790.reviewBody: The whole goal of my trip to Cuernavaca was to view the murals that Rivera completed on a backside patio of the Palacio de Cortes. From DF, Cuernavaca is an easy day trip by first class bus from the Terminal Sur. Due to Saturday morning traffic getting out of town, the 1 1/4 hour trip took closer to 2 hours. However, with little traffic on the return trip, we made the voyage in the expected amount of time. Take the bus that arrives at the Centro terminal, not the Casino one. The Centro terminal is just a few blocks off the zocalo where you\'ll find the palace. After a quick cup on the Plaza de Armas, I headed straight for the palace. For a Saturday, I was surprised and delighted by the light crowd at the museum. I have to admit that I didn\'t focus on most of the collection, except a section of the museum that highlighted Emiliano Zapata and the Mexican Revolution, but rather beelined straight for the Rivera murals. Although the patio is relatively small, I had the entire mural to myself for more than a half hour. Rivera completed this mural in the mid-1920s. It presents scenes from the Conquest up through the 1910 revolution. Many of the scenes depict the cruelty of the conquistadors to the indigenous peoples. The scene entitled "The Ravine" is particularly captivating and the most memorable highlight of the entire mural. Although I could have easily spent more time focused on other aspects of the marvelous collection and building, Cortes really did build a fortress for himself, my time spent with the Rivera mural made my entire trip to Cueranvaca worthwhile. For some photos of the mural check out my travel blog at http://searchingfordiego.blogspot.com.

126503103.name: Interesting mixture of exhibits
126503103.author: a TripAdvisor user
126503103.reviewBody: Like most sites in and around Cuernavaca, this location loses some benefit for non-Spanish speaking visitors as virtually everything is in Spanish.   The entry fee is about $3 each with a similar charge if you want to use a camera.  The displays range from pre-historic charts of flora and fauna to armour worn by Cortes\' soldiers.   Different rooms showed different eras of the state of Moralos.  Few visitors while we were there.  Located in the centre of town, called Zocalo.

125828854.name: Alfredo - Thank you for the Experience!
125828854.author: a TripAdvisor user
125828854.reviewBody: I visited the museum alone and really didn\'t know what anything was as I do not understand Spanish.  I walked through the museum and everything was amazing, however once I met Alfredo - then everything came together.  He is an excellent interpreter and the stories were so interesting.  I am so happy with my book and scarf I am going to frame - but I am so sorry I missed seeing him as he was going to help me to paint a picture like the one hanging in the museum of Cuernavaca.\n\nI will return Alfredo - and I will paint that picture!  Cuernavaca is so beautiful - People - come to Cuernavaca - there is not problem here - honestly...they need tourism to help their economy.  All-inclusive goers - this is an experience and if you read the recent Wealthy Barber he speaks about spending money on experiences - THIS IS IT!  It is so beautiful - Taxco - omg is amazing....wow so much to see.....

125675765.name: Palacio put to good use
125675765.author: a TripAdvisor user
125675765.reviewBody: Wonderful museum, well signed.  Could be a little easier if there were some signs in English

125398593.name: Palacio de Cortes
125398593.author: a TripAdvisor user
125398593.reviewBody: Excellent Museum, had great cross section of battles, traditions and every day life.

124979976.name: Very interesting!!!
124979976.author: a TripAdvisor user
124979976.reviewBody: Visit this very interesting museum to learn more abot the history of Cuernavaca. On Sundays the entrance is for free.

123457050.name: An important historical site in Cuernavaca!
123457050.author: a TripAdvisor user
123457050.reviewBody: Interesting historical place!!! a MUSTif you travel to Cuernavaca!

123297419.name: well worth a visit
123297419.author: a TripAdvisor user
123297419.reviewBody: We really went only for the Diego Rivera mural, but were surprised by the quality and quantity of well-preserved archaeological items.  Only some things are explained in English, but, even so, the museum is worthwhile.  It is quite diverse...there is much to see apart from the ancient objects relating to the indigenous peoples

123114170.name: its an interesting museum
123114170.author: a TripAdvisor user
123114170.reviewBody: you should take a look at this museum in cuernavaca got a lot of details of the mexican historic

122540912.name: Wonderful architecture
122540912.author: a TripAdvisor user
122540912.reviewBody: A museum of Cuernavaca\'s rich history. I would of liked to see more consistency in providing bilingual plaques on all exhibits, however this small, lovely museum can be enjoyed within one afternoon.

122053016.name: Lots to see, easy to follow, low cost!
122053016.author: a TripAdvisor user
122053016.reviewBody: 4 female adults 25-50yo. Great 2-3 hour visit in the central part of town. The outdoor view is a memorable feature with a huge statue of Cortes out front. At the entrance, there is a glass-covered grave. Indoors, each piece has a lengthy description with dates and locations, which was easy to translate to English through simple word association. We did not pay for a guide and were very happy with our self-guided tour. There are many interesting artifacts including slave branding irons, weapons, royal tapestry, and even Diego Rivera murals. There are benches throughout the museum, because there is a lot of walking including stairs. Pictures allowed everywhere, bathrooms are clean and free with purchase of entry to the museum. I believe it was about 40pesos per person to enter, definitely under 80. Large bags must be checked at the front desk, but there is no cost for this. There is a small gift shop inside with various books and artwork, but I would DEFINITELY recommend walking through the markets adjacent to the museum to see handmade leather works, jewelry and embroidered bags. I would take future visitors to the museum and market, but would not need to go inside the museum again otherwise.

121864496.name: Diego Rivera Murals
121864496.author: a TripAdvisor user
121864496.reviewBody: This is a very good place to see some very famous Diego Rivera Murals

121804494.name: nice museum
121804494.author: a TripAdvisor user
121804494.reviewBody: nice museum, it a good place to visit while in Cuernavaca. It is next to the main square so you can do and se many things before and after. The silver market right next to it is the best, don\'t miss it.

120740132.name: Cortes, but where is la Malinche?
120740132.author: a TripAdvisor user
120740132.reviewBody: Another fine museum in Cuernavaca.  Obvious visit, the Diego Rivera murals.  Hope you are reading up on Mexico\'s history so you really get a feel for these places. (La Lacuna by Barbara Kingsolver is a good historical fiction, if you\'re not into \'history\'.)

119558129.name: walking tour
119558129.author: a TripAdvisor user
119558129.reviewBody: I love the palaces and the history of the spanish influence in Mexico. The zocalo and area around the Palace are great for a walking tour that can last over many days.

117922068.name: Awesome; kids really liked it, as did we. Lots to learn, and very well done.
117922068.author: a TripAdvisor user
117922068.reviewBody: Fantastic way to spend the morning. I just wish they had more information in English.

73223991.name: The murals are definitely worth going to...
73223991.author: a TripAdvisor user
73223991.reviewBody: The murals are definitely worth going to see along with the view of old cuernavaca. They are landscaping the front at the moment which will definitely add to The charm of The place when complete

22531153.name: A wonderful museum and historical attraction
22531153.author: a TripAdvisor user
22531153.reviewBody: Cortes built this fortress like palace after conquering the Aztecs and on top of a indigenous site. He and his family lived there for a while. It has served a variety of purposes over the years but is now a terrific museum. As you wind your way around the galleries you learn a great deal about the history of Mexico in chronological order and the written descriptions are in both Spanish and English. It is all done very well and is just a minute or two from he main plaza in downtown Cuernavaca. Don\'t miss the backside porch with the enormous Rivera murals covering his historical look back at Mexico. It too is an outstanding treat.

17265087.name: Stunning Murals!
17265087.author: a TripAdvisor user
17265087.reviewBody: The Palacio was built in the 1500\'s by Hernan Cortez as his personal residence, and purposely situated right on top of some Mayan ruins.  Talk about adding insult to injury.  It now features a panoramic though condensed  view of Mexican history and culture from BC to the 20th century.  The most stunning exhibit for me was upstairs on the second floor portico: the large mural by Diego Rivera of the conquest of Cuernavaca by Cortez and his soldiers and priests.  Very moving.  Take your time with it, there\'s lots to see there.

661328660.name: Tours are Available
661328660.author: a TripAdvisor user
661328660.reviewBody: There is a local guide available in the plaza that gave me a 90 minute tour.  Lots of interesting history.  There are actually three churches within the plaza.

itemReviewed.name: Cathedral of the Asencion (Catedral de la Asuncion)

652043034.name: Nice Cathedral
652043034.author: a TripAdvisor user
652043034.reviewBody: We entered the premises of the complex which constitutes the main Cathedral church with a few minor churches, considered though here as chapels, and the monastery buildings annexed. The complex is part of the Unesco site comprising early 16th century monasteries in the vicinity of the Popocatepetl volcano and was thus built purposely to convert the local indigenous population after the Spanish conquest. This is why the whole complex is surrounded by walls, typical for those monasteries, which could then defend themselves in case of attacks. The Cathedral church suffered partial reconstructions and refurbishments which altered its aspect, especially in the interior. The exterior though is typical of the colonial style in vogue during the 16th century. Unfortunately, I could only admire the complex from the interior courtyard because the interior of the church and chapels was closed due to the earthquake

itemReviewed.name: Cathedral of the Asencion (Catedral de la Asuncion)

649916669.name: Holy Place
649916669.author: a TripAdvisor user
649916669.reviewBody: Cathedral is a classic colonial building which barely survived the 2017 earthquake. The main altar is decorated in golden covered wood and the ceremonies are touching.

itemReviewed.name: Cathedral of the Asencion (Catedral de la Asuncion)

645175815.name: History. Church visit
645175815.author: a TripAdvisor user
645175815.reviewBody: If you are a history buff; this is an ideal place to encounter Cortes. The lay out of the Cathedral, the "recinto" is fantastic and a delightful visit.

itemReviewed.name: Cathedral of the Asencion (Catedral de la Asuncion)

643874139.name: Simple colonial church
643874139.author: a TripAdvisor user
643874139.reviewBody: Compared to the nearby cathedral and chapel, this small church is very simple but well maintained and serene compare to the others.

itemReviewed.name: Cathedral of the Asencion (Catedral de la Asuncion)

641365944.name: Early 16th century
641365944.author: a TripAdvisor user
641365944.reviewBody: One of the most beautiful and intricate church santuaries I have seen.  Built of native stone, it has survived a lot of earthquakes.

itemReviewed.name: Cathedral of the Asencion (Catedral de la Asuncion)

636763275.name: Cannot go in
636763275.author: a TripAdvisor user
636763275.reviewBody: This is still under renovation after the earthquake, but there is an interesting outside atrium area with frescos and two small chapels on the site.

itemReviewed.name: Cathedral of the Asencion (Catedral de la Asuncion)

580008150.name: Good visit
580008150.author: a TripAdvisor user
580008150.reviewBody: This cathedral was very popular and the overall area is pretty big. The main sanctuary was closed off probably because of the earthquake but another sanctuary was open to service. It\u2019s very well kept and clean. It\u2019s a great place to visit with your friends, family, or as a couple.

itemReviewed.name: Cathedral of the Asencion (Catedral de la Asuncion)

570176888.name: Earthquake Damage Makes Portions Inaccessible
570176888.author: a TripAdvisor user
570176888.reviewBody: We were somewhat restricted because the recent earthquakes have caused some damage which leaves portions unavailable, including the main building. However, we saw a portion of a mass in one of the smaller buildings and greatly enjoyed the grounds.

itemReviewed.name: Cathedral of the Asencion (Catedral de la Asuncion)

555517456.name: A landmark of Cuernavaca
555517456.author: a TripAdvisor user
555517456.reviewBody: Every visitor to Cuernavaca needs to go to "La Catedral" which is a beautiful church and convent of the XVI century. Since the earthquake of September 19, the cathedral had damages and now it is close the main church and some chapels (The Cathedral of Cuernavaca is a group of a Main church and 3 chapels), we hope ti will be open soon.

itemReviewed.name: Cathedral of the Asencion (Catedral de la Asuncion)

673491314.name: Nice archeological site, beautiful town! Visit Malinalco, near Cuernavaca.
673491314.author: a TripAdvisor user
673491314.reviewBody: Malinalco is a beautiful and safe town near Cuernavaca. The archeological site is also nice. The food is delicious. The hotel and restaurantes are not expensive.

address.streetAddress: Carretera Federal Xochicalco Tetlama, sin numero Xochicalco, Municipio de Miacatlan, Morelos

661338206.name: No vendors!
661338206.author: a TripAdvisor user
661338206.reviewBody:
This is the only archaeological site in Mexico I have been to that does not have vendors.  It makes for a much more relaxing and enjoyable experience.  This site also has one of the few remnants of stucco covered adobe.

The museum has a surprisingly large collection considering the location.  All the signage is Spanish-only.

The site is a bit difficult for foreigners to get to.  You will need to rent a car or hire a driver to get there.

address.streetAddress: Carretera Federal Xochicalco Tetlama, sin numero Xochicalco, Municipio de Miacatlan, Morelos

656067900.name: Worth the effort if youve not visited many mexican archeological sites, perhaps less so otherwise
656067900.author: a TripAdvisor user
656067900.reviewBody:
This is quite an interesting site and recommended if you've not had the opportunity to visit any of the other archaeological cites in and around Mexico City. However, if like us you've already been to Teotihuacan , Monte Alban, Mitla and Xochimilco then you might not find it so fascinating as the site, whilst a reasonable size, is not as well preserved. Unfortunately too, the observertary, which we were particularly interested in seeing is still closed following the Sept 17 earthquake. The site does, nevertheless, have a couple of well preserved ball courts.

There is a small museum included in the entrance fee of 75 pesos which was ok and has some English explanation. The archelogical site also has some interpretative panels in English and Spanish but not as many as the other sites we've visited.

Xochicalco can also be a bit tricky to get to as it's pretty isolated - and hot so take plenty of water and some snacks. We spent around 1.5 hours here. We took the 10.04 bus from the station almost opposite Casa Colonial Hotel, near the centre of Cuernavaca, but I think this only operates on weekends. The journey on a nice coach took 1 hour and cost 47 pesos. 

Returning was slightly more hit and miss. Originally we planned to get an uber which came up at a reasonable cost of 220 pesos but with a half hour wait. We saw a few local buses coming and going and although not clear from the destination shown, we found one going to Cuernavaca within 10 minutes for 19 pesos! Comfortable one too. Don't know if we just got lucky.

My last suggestion is to put on or take insect repent with you as this has been the only place we've found lots of horrible biting things that look like big flying ants - and they really hurt!

address.streetAddress: Carretera Federal Xochicalco Tetlama, sin numero Xochicalco, Municipio de Miacatlan, Morelos

654133243.name: Must-see Archeological Highlight near Cuernavaca
654133243.author: a TripAdvisor user
654133243.reviewBody: A beautiful site, small enough to see in two hours. We travelled there with an extraordinary guide, Arturo Galindo, (1taxiseguro.com) who made the experience even more memorable with his fluent English and attentiveness to our safety.  Hats, water, and sunscreen mandatory!

address.streetAddress: Carretera Federal Xochicalco Tetlama, sin numero Xochicalco, Municipio de Miacatlan, Morelos

652224877.name: If you\'re going to visit a couple of archaeological sites in central Mexico, Xochicalco should be one of them!
652224877.author: a TripAdvisor user
652224877.reviewBody: After visiting over the years many archaeological sites of different cultures in Mexico, it\'s always a pleasure to return to Xochicalco (pronounced \'Sotchycalco\') located about half an hour\'s drive south of the city of Cuernavaca, in the State of Morelos.  What makes this site quite unique among others is its location on a large hill that overlooks an open valley where the hill itself is an integral part of the archaelogical site.  There are a number of platforms distributed at different levels of the hill that hold either a ceremonial center, the remains of living quarters, or the ancient ball courts.  At the top is the temple dedicated to Quetzalcoatl, the feathered serpent, with bas-reliefs sculptured on all four walls of the ceremonial center. It\'s fun to climb the various wide staircases leading from one level to another, stop at each and enjoy the view of varying landscapes, which may include trees, agaves, and other assorted greenery.  You can descend the archeological zone from the opposite side you entered, so there\'s no need to backtrack on your visit.\nXochicalco reached its heigth around 1,000 AD when the Toltecs were the dominant culture in Mexico\'s central valley, although it would be a far-out generalization to name the city-state\'s inhabitants \'Toltecs\'.  They were skilled merchants and traded with distant civilizations in all cardinal directions, including the Mayans in the now far away Yucatan, the Zapotecs and Mixtecs to the south in the present State of Oaxaca, as well as the various cultures in the central valley of Mexico (now Mexico City) or the Gulf Coast.  To start your visit of Xochicalco, don\'t miss the not-too-long exhibits, maps, and explanations in the welcoming pavilion at the entrance to the archaeological zone.  It will make your visit that much more rewarding.  Enjoy!

address.streetAddress: Carretera Federal Xochicalco Tetlama, sin numero Xochicalco, Municipio de Miacatlan, Morelos

646000144.name: Well preserved and nice archeological site
646000144.author: a TripAdvisor user
646000144.reviewBody: Located south of Cuernavaca, 1.15 hrs from Mexico City, this site shows elements of the Aztec Culture like ball game and pyramid-based temples.

address.streetAddress: Carretera Federal Xochicalco Tetlama, sin numero Xochicalco, Municipio de Miacatlan, Morelos

639795068.name: Up,  Down and All Around
639795068.author: a TripAdvisor user
639795068.reviewBody: We loved visiting these ruins.  Our guide said the area dates back to the Toltecs.  Much of the ruins are very well preserved.  There is much climbing and walking so be sure to have comfy shoes.

address.streetAddress: Carretera Federal Xochicalco Tetlama, sin numero Xochicalco, Municipio de Miacatlan, Morelos

637905836.name: Great museum and archaeological site
637905836.author: a TripAdvisor user
637905836.reviewBody: Xochicalco is a great museum with signs in multiple languages. My family visited the archaeological site as a self guided tour. We enjoyed the sites tremendously!

address.streetAddress: Carretera Federal Xochicalco Tetlama, sin numero Xochicalco, Municipio de Miacatlan, Morelos

637305582.name: Outstanding
637305582.author: a TripAdvisor user
637305582.reviewBody: Well preserved and fascinating. The museum is outstanding, and the underground observatory is like another world. It is sunny and hot in the area, so be sure to wear a hat.

address.streetAddress: Carretera Federal Xochicalco Tetlama, sin numero Xochicalco, Municipio de Miacatlan, Morelos

634468913.name: Very under visited
634468913.author: a TripAdvisor user
634468913.reviewBody: I think this is the most beautiful temple in Central Mexico that we visited with its spectacular setting, beautiful carvings, lovely site--including living quarters for the elite in the "Acropolis" and the fantastic museum.  One warning--we could not find food nearby--I would recommend bringing a picnic along (we bought some bananas and peanuts in town).

address.streetAddress: Carretera Federal Xochicalco Tetlama, sin numero Xochicalco, Municipio de Miacatlan, Morelos

634279628.name: Great archaeological site and a very good guide
634279628.author: a TripAdvisor user
634279628.reviewBody: My wife and I visited Xochicalco with our guide Carlos Cortes. This is a very interesting site with a good museum which had a lot of good material.
