There is also a very informative and enjoyable museum that educates you on all things Xochicalco.

address.streetAddress: Carretera Federal Xochicalco Tetlama, sin numero Xochicalco, Municipio de Miacatlan, Morelos

191546413.name: Must visit for history lovers
191546413.author: a TripAdvisor user
191546413.reviewBody:
This is something which shows that Engineering in the olden days was just as good as today! 

Xochicalco is a pre-Columbian archaeological site in the Municipality of Miacatlán in the western part of the Mexican state of Morelos.The site is located 38 km southwest of Cuernavaca, about 76 miles by road from Mexico City. The site is open to visitors all week, from 10 am to 5 pm, although access to the observatory is only allowed after noon. The apogee of Xochicalco came after the fall of Teotihuacan and it has been speculated that Xochicalco may have played a part in the fall of the Teotihuacan empire.

I had a wonderful experience visiting this place when I visit Xochicalco in may 2010, I took a Bus from Mexico city to Cuernavaca and from their I took a taxi to Xochicalco,I had asked him to stay for a round trip. After enjoying the place for 2-3 hours I decided to head back to catch my bus back to Mexico city only to find out that the taxi driver had left me. I being a stranger who cant speak Spanish had a tough time and adding in salt to injury i didnt have enough pesos to pay for an other taxi (I had GBP) later Luckily I found few British travelers who took GBP and gave me Pesos to travel back to Cuernavaca. I however found a couple travelling to Cuernavaca  and they dropped me to the bus stand and helped me get back safe!

All in all a great trip. Given a chance will love to visit the place again.

address.streetAddress: Carretera Federal Xochicalco Tetlama, sin numero Xochicalco, Municipio de Miacatlan, Morelos

185795747.name: Magical site
185795747.author: a TripAdvisor user
185795747.reviewBody: An archeological site of great importance in Mexican culture, a magical site, wonderful views and great energy!

address.streetAddress: Carretera Federal Xochicalco Tetlama, sin numero Xochicalco, Municipio de Miacatlan, Morelos

180484771.name: Off the beaten track but well worth the effort to get there
180484771.author: a TripAdvisor user
180484771.reviewBody: This place sits majestically at the crest of a mountain. Approaching from the valley below its first visual sighting is amazing. It sits like a white crown on top of the mountain. The museum to the right as you enter (and where you must but tickets) is ok but not amazing so spend your time on the excavation. Don\'t miss the incredibly detailed "serpent" pyramid at the top and Also venture down and thru the largest ball court (on the left side of the place as you enter) to get to a cave in the back where an astrological hole has been made in the ceiling. When the sun shines it determines the exact seasons. They only let a few people in at a time so be prepared to wait 10-15 min. For your turn.

address.streetAddress: Carretera Federal Xochicalco Tetlama, sin numero Xochicalco, Municipio de Miacatlan, Morelos

180284986.name: Great view and interesting archeology.
180284986.author: a TripAdvisor user
180284986.reviewBody: The zone of Xochicalco is the best in the state of Morelos, and of great interest as it is the first report  of a  \u201dscientific congress\u201d in the Americas. A small pyramid completely covered with sculpture reports this event form ore then thousand years ago, where Mayan and highland priests share their calendar knowledge.\nThis is particularly obvious to the left of the staircase where a hand and a string connect two highland symbols to a Mayan one.\nGreat excursion\u00f1 it can be combined with a trip to Taxco and possible the caves of Cacahamilpa.

address.streetAddress: Carretera Federal Xochicalco Tetlama, sin numero Xochicalco, Municipio de Miacatlan, Morelos

176248549.name: Outstanding heritage site
176248549.author: a TripAdvisor user
176248549.reviewBody: Even with out speaking the language you will be breathless just walking around the archeological site. The 45 minute drive from Cuernavaca is completely worthy.

address.streetAddress: Carretera Federal Xochicalco Tetlama, sin numero Xochicalco, Municipio de Miacatlan, Morelos

173721365.name: Xochicalco, beautiful
173721365.author: a TripAdvisor user
173721365.reviewBody: Well worth the trip.  I would recommend arriving in the morning so you are not walking around in the high heat of mid afternoon.  Take your time through the museum, there are some amazing pieces there.\n\nThere used to be self lead guide books and headphones so you could meander at your own pace.  The recording was excellent and well worth the money.  They offered this in many languages, sadly they don\'t offer it anymore.  Wonder if enough people asked for it that they would bring it back.

address.streetAddress: Carretera Federal Xochicalco Tetlama, sin numero Xochicalco, Municipio de Miacatlan, Morelos

167984652.name: The complex, the views, and most of all the cave
167984652.author: a TripAdvisor user
167984652.reviewBody: A fantastic experience - but I very strongly recommend hiring one of the on-site guides for 450pesos (less than $40). Ours was Gabriel...he was a wealth of information and made the ruins (beautifully preserved / reconstructed ) come to life. He spent almost 3 hours with us, and spoke flawless English and so clearly and slowly in Spanish that I was able to follow his narrative almost completely in that language (and I am far from fluent). The complex is quite large but digestible. The truly phenomenal highlights were the Temple of the Feathered Serpent ( with many square meters of magnificent  bas reliefs, totally unique in Mesoamerica ) and the "chimney" leading p from the interior of the cave through which the sun shines its light for 20 minutes or so at midday, piercing the dark with a ray that feels like something out of a science fiction movie. if you are visiting Cuernavaca ( a very disappointing place ) this will make it worth it.

address.streetAddress: Carretera Federal Xochicalco Tetlama, sin numero Xochicalco, Municipio de Miacatlan, Morelos

165338546.name: Great views and interesting site
165338546.author: a TripAdvisor user
165338546.reviewBody: A large site with important calendar significance.  Great vistas and very few people.  Be sure to see the caves with a shaft of light to indicate the solstice.

address.streetAddress: Carretera Federal Xochicalco Tetlama, sin numero Xochicalco, Municipio de Miacatlan, Morelos

160456076.name: You must see it !!!
160456076.author: a TripAdvisor user
160456076.reviewBody:
This site has something really special. No it doesn't have big pyramides or big temples. But this is an "all". The constructions are really well preserved, the both ballcourt are like new or almost. And what to say about the Temple of the Feathered Serpent. This is a masterpiece! The site is build on a hill, this folk worked this hill like a pyramide. At the top, you have a good view on the valley.  

The museum is really well too. It has many impressive pieces. If you've see Teotihuacan, this site is the logical suite and must be seen. No many tourist go there, simply because it's situation is not favorable. No beach near and Mexico city is quite far. It have direct bus from Cuernavace only the weekend. You can take a taxi for 400 pesos to go there. 

We went at this site in april, this was really hot these day (don't forget water bottle) and a little fog of humidity masked the view of paysage. That was most yellow than green because everything was dry. This site must be really beautiful after the rain season.  

It only had one thing sadly about this site. During our visit, we've see a colomn of black smoke near of the site. An employed of the site explain us than it have a mine just beside and that will made a lot of polution an destroy the view of the paysage. We find this really sadly for this site who is a Unesco site. Than I encorage you to visit this site, if this touch you, write at the museum No a la Mina. It will made an other argument against the mine for protect this site.

address.streetAddress: Carretera Federal Xochicalco Tetlama, sin numero Xochicalco, Municipio de Miacatlan, Morelos

160321363.name: Fantastic hilltop city not far from Cuernavaca
160321363.author: a TripAdvisor user
160321363.reviewBody: Another great archaeological site well worth a day trip from Mexico City and environs. The buildings are nicely restored and the hilltop setting is impressive: you can see why the founders chose this important location overlooking the surrounding area.  The museum is small and nicely organized.

address.streetAddress: Carretera Federal Xochicalco Tetlama, sin numero Xochicalco, Municipio de Miacatlan, Morelos

155995658.name: Excellent archaeological site!
155995658.author: a TripAdvisor user
155995658.reviewBody: The archeological site is great, there\'s an awesome view and a very informative museum. In spring it can be too hot, so try and go early in the morning.

address.streetAddress: Carretera Federal Xochicalco Tetlama, sin numero Xochicalco, Municipio de Miacatlan, Morelos

155151416.name: 2+ enjoyable hours of history
155151416.author: a TripAdvisor user
155151416.reviewBody:
Our tour guide Angel Flores drove us here at our request.   Had to pay $57 pesos/ea and another $400 for a guide.  Twice what I was expecting, but in the end we were satisfied.  Our guide, Hugo spoke English well and knew lots of cultural history.  (He studied history and archeology in the States). He answered all of our many questions and we did not feel rushed through the tour.

They now have some lighting in the observatory, but there isn't that much to see there.  There are enough ruins to climb up to work up a sweat, but the view from the top is spectacular.  Learned that the human sacrifices were not slaves, but the priests themselves would sacrifice their organs or lives.

We chose this over tehuacalco thinking there was more to see.  I can't tell you how they compare, but we really enjoyed our time here.  FYIW Hugo said that tour guides are not paid a salary but work strictly as "work for hire" for visitors.  I would've been disappointed to be w/o an English-speaking guide who knows the ruins well.  There may be better guides but Hugo exceeded my expectations.  You can find him at goxochicalcotours.com.

address.streetAddress: Carretera Federal Xochicalco Tetlama, sin numero Xochicalco, Municipio de Miacatlan, Morelos

154590228.name: Unique place
154590228.author: a TripAdvisor user
154590228.reviewBody: It\'s a very good place to take your children. Because they need to learn some history and, guess what? Xochicalco is Mexican history baby. No toys, no TV, no "viva la vida loca". This is authentic, and it\'s Da Bomb.

address.streetAddress: Carretera Federal Xochicalco Tetlama, sin numero Xochicalco, Municipio de Miacatlan, Morelos

153225585.name: Museums
153225585.author: a TripAdvisor user
153225585.reviewBody: Brady museum is a fantastic art museum with wonderful gardens and the palace history of the area is wonderful

address.streetAddress: Carretera Federal Xochicalco Tetlama, sin numero Xochicalco, Municipio de Miacatlan, Morelos

151018278.name: Unesco site
151018278.author: a TripAdvisor user
151018278.reviewBody: The place is fantastic not only because of the archeological remains, incl the beautiful quetzalcoatl pyramide, but the astonishing viewes and the museum which is both interesting and modern, but only in spanish

address.streetAddress: Carretera Federal Xochicalco Tetlama, sin numero Xochicalco, Municipio de Miacatlan, Morelos

149297883.name: Well Worth the Visit
149297883.author: a TripAdvisor user
149297883.reviewBody: Teotihuacan tends to get the majority of the attention in Central Mexico in regards to ruins.  However, my husband and I thought Xochicalco was better.  It is smaller in size, but the location on top of the hill makes for some stunning views.  Plus there were zero vendors, and few tourists.  We even got to go inside the ruins and see the moonlight.  Very cool!

address.streetAddress: Carretera Federal Xochicalco Tetlama, sin numero Xochicalco, Municipio de Miacatlan, Morelos

149234837.name: Lots to see, Not a lot of other visitors
149234837.author: a TripAdvisor user
149234837.reviewBody: If you\'re in Cuernavaca, this is definitely worth the trip. The ruins are well preserved and have a scenic location high up in the hills. The cave where light shoots down from the ceiling is among the coolest things I saw on my trip. There\'s also a nice new eco-friendly museum with interesting artifacts.

address.streetAddress: Carretera Federal Xochicalco Tetlama, sin numero Xochicalco, Municipio de Miacatlan, Morelos

148548393.name: Great to check out
148548393.author: a TripAdvisor user
148548393.reviewBody: Tour guide leaves much to be desired (not all I\'m sure).  Setting is very interesting.  I\'ve seen other ruins which I found more appealing and interesting.

address.streetAddress: Carretera Federal Xochicalco Tetlama, sin numero Xochicalco, Municipio de Miacatlan, Morelos

148433108.name: Terrific experience
148433108.author: a TripAdvisor user
148433108.reviewBody: From the modern museum entrance to the beautiful vistas from the site everything about these ruins was incredible. The people who originally settled here sure picked the ultimate site. One of the best in central Mexico

address.streetAddress: Carretera Federal Xochicalco Tetlama, sin numero Xochicalco, Municipio de Miacatlan, Morelos

148401824.name: Beautiful and impressive
148401824.author: a TripAdvisor user
148401824.reviewBody:
If you are remotely interested in Pre-Columbian culture then this site is unmissable if you are near the Cuernavaca area. It is not as spectacular in scale as Teotihuacan but is, I think, more subtle. The elevated site also makes for great views of the surrounding countryside including Lake Tequesquitengo. You can reach Xochicalco by car from Mexico City but it is a bit of a trek. Other reviews have established how fantastic it is. I will only suggest you bring the following items: camera, food, water, sun hat (!), sun block. Apart from the camera, we forgot all the others today. Bad idea as it was baking.

Besides the ruins, the jewel of which is the temple of the plumed serpents, there is also a great museum although all the interpretation is in Spanish only. It is disappointing too that there is no shop selling books and related Xochicalco paraphernalia.

For the less abled-bodied, it is worth pointing out that there is quite a bit of up and down around the site.

address.streetAddress: Carretera Federal Xochicalco Tetlama, sin numero Xochicalco, Municipio de Miacatlan, Morelos

146258338.name: Toltec-Mayan Calendar
146258338.author: a TripAdvisor user
146258338.reviewBody: A beautiful archaeoloical site near Cuernavaca.  This is a fantastic site.  No pyramids but extensive network of temples and ball courts.  The importance of the site seems to have been a meeting place of Toltec and Mayan priests closely associated with their calendar systems.  The presence of seated Mayan priests is unique in this area of Mesoamerica.  The mayan and Toltec iconography of the Temple of the Plumed Serpent or Quetzalcoatl seems to indicate the unity of the two calendar systems.  Check out some of the caves on the hillsides.  The caves contain chimneys and stone floors to trace the movement of the stars.  This site is the only place in Mexico that demonstrates how the heavens were studies.  I loved this site.  Get a guide for better or for worse.

address.streetAddress: Carretera Federal Xochicalco Tetlama, sin numero Xochicalco, Municipio de Miacatlan, Morelos

146244783.name: Beautiful site with a great view
146244783.author: a TripAdvisor user
146244783.reviewBody: I\'m really glad I went here. This is outside the Maya domain, but there are a lot of Maya styles used, as well as those of the Teotihuacanos. If one is not on an organized tour, one may take a bus from Cuernavaca. The site is on top of a very tall hill, and it is quite a distance to get to the hill from the main road, and then a lot of uphill walking. If one is not very fit, or is pressed for time, it would be best to take a taxi or bus all the way up the hill from Cuernavaca itself. There is a museum a couple hundred metres from the site entrance, from which site entry tickets may be purchased, and at which various artifacts may be viewed. Since it is high up, the site is a bit cooler  than base of the hill.\n\nAt the site itself, there\'s a lot to see, including ball courts, the entrance plaza flanked by two lesser pyramids, the observatory (to see the sunbeam enter the observation chamber, it is best to visit around midday), the acropolis, the main plaza, and the main pyramid itself. Then there\'s the grand attraction at the main plaza: the Temple of the Feathered Serpent, which is covered with beautiful carvings that are in fairly good shape.

address.streetAddress: Carretera Federal Xochicalco Tetlama, sin numero Xochicalco, Municipio de Miacatlan, Morelos

145902218.name: Step back in time
145902218.author: a TripAdvisor user
145902218.reviewBody: The most eye opening part of my visit to Xochicalco, were the game fields. I remember watching a Disney movie with my son where they played the game, and when I saw the actual field, I immediately took a picture and sent to my son. The stories about what the meetings that took place here were fascinating. Our guide took each engraving and explained what they meant. It really amazes you that all of this took place thousands of years ago. If you are in this area, please go, well worth the visit.

address.streetAddress: Carretera Federal Xochicalco Tetlama, sin numero Xochicalco, Municipio de Miacatlan, Morelos

145605237.name: Some unique views of history
145605237.author: a TripAdvisor user
145605237.reviewBody: As in all the ancient historic sites I have visited, Xochicalco offers its own unique look at life in the classic period.  Particularly interesting at this site, are the ball courts, one of which still boasts the rings mounted in the walls (this was the first I have seen), the observatory that consists of a cave modified to include a \'chimney\' about 27 feet long using the sun to determine specific points in time and the temple of the feathered serpent.  The museum boasts a number of artifacts from the site and information signs are in english.  A local guide can give you a better understanding of the site and the culture.  Well worth a visit

address.streetAddress: Carretera Federal Xochicalco Tetlama, sin numero Xochicalco, Municipio de Miacatlan, Morelos

145400611.name: Spectacular!
145400611.author: a TripAdvisor user
145400611.reviewBody: Well worth the drive from Cuernavaca - a highlight of our trip. Stunning views and don\'t miss the cave.

address.streetAddress: Carretera Federal Xochicalco Tetlama, sin numero Xochicalco, Municipio de Miacatlan, Morelos

144396620.name: hire a guide to learn more
144396620.author: a TripAdvisor user
144396620.reviewBody: It is a stunning site, being restored and has a fantastic museum and view. The guide to us into the observatory, had lots of history to share and made it very rich. Had also been in the spring of 2012 but this time there seemed to be a bit more english signage.

address.streetAddress: Carretera Federal Xochicalco Tetlama, sin numero Xochicalco, Municipio de Miacatlan, Morelos

142984963.name: Awesome: In the true meaning of the word
142984963.author: a TripAdvisor user
142984963.reviewBody: This place is huge. And beautiful. And jam-packed with history. (We had an excellent guide, or we would not have known all this history.) Its vistas are far-ranging, and the sophistication of the people who designed and built it is staggering. They had a sewer system! In the 7th century! It is a beautiful site. We even crept in the dark into the mountain observatory. Strenuous climbing (I am 70) well worth every huff and puff.

address.streetAddress: Carretera Federal Xochicalco Tetlama, sin numero Xochicalco, Municipio de Miacatlan, Morelos

138794249.name: Do NOT Miss This Site
138794249.author: a TripAdvisor user
138794249.reviewBody: These ruins are not easy to find, so get a driver to take you if possible.  UNESCO has done an incredible job of preserving this antiquity.  The museum is very very well done, with big beautiful rooms and plenty of light.  The site itself is spectacular, especially if you have never seen any ruins before, which I had not.  We also happened upon a gentleman who gave us a tour of the observatory, which we would have never found without him.  Stunning, stunning, stunning exhibit of humans from our past.

address.streetAddress: Carretera Federal Xochicalco Tetlama, sin numero Xochicalco, Municipio de Miacatlan, Morelos

135473874.name: Ruins are amazing, but getting there by public bus is very difficult.
135473874.author: a TripAdvisor user
135473874.reviewBody: I guess if I had rented a car it would have been easy getting there, but I went by bus from Mexico City, and while getting there was not really difficult, getting out was a different mater altogether, since I had to walk for miles getting down to the highway, there were no bus services from the ruins to the town.\nAs for the ruins themselves there quite nice and since they are on to of a hill, it looks even more impressive, the feather serpent\'s pyramid is one of the most beautiful and underrated in the whole of Mexico, well worth going (if you plan ahead or provide your own transport).

address.streetAddress: Carretera Federal Xochicalco Tetlama, sin numero Xochicalco, Municipio de Miacatlan, Morelos

133315958.name: Magical view!
133315958.author: a TripAdvisor user
133315958.reviewBody: Beautiful big ruins that are little visited. Magical view to the countryside, pyramid dedicated to the Feathered Serpent god, various "juegos de pelota", underground observatory!!! If you go to Taxco or Cuernavaca, visiting Xochicalco is a must. Unless you have your own transport, it is complicated to get to ( thought there are some local buses that leave from Cuernavaca).

address.streetAddress: Carretera Federal Xochicalco Tetlama, sin numero Xochicalco, Municipio de Miacatlan, Morelos

130971269.name: Amazing ruins
130971269.author: a TripAdvisor user
130971269.reviewBody: Most of the Mexicans do not visit or have never visited this location, a must for those interested in archeology.

address.streetAddress: Carretera Federal Xochicalco Tetlama, sin numero Xochicalco, Municipio de Miacatlan, Morelos

129481600.name: Marvelous
129481600.author: a TripAdvisor user
129481600.reviewBody: One of the 11 or 13 marvels; can\'t remember which.We were the only two tourists there on a Monday morning. It\'s a great site with wonderful view of the surrounding valley. The air is dry and fragrant; the ruins well-manicured, and the little museum has wonderful finds. They do a light show here, so it must get packed during holidays, vacation, etc.

address.streetAddress: Carretera Federal Xochicalco Tetlama, sin numero Xochicalco, Municipio de Miacatlan, Morelos

129125579.name: Top 3 of the center of the country
129125579.author: a TripAdvisor user
129125579.reviewBody: this site has a wonderfull view, a unique temple dedicated to feather snake god with amazing sculptures on it, a exceptional astronomical cave. The site is normaly quiet and peacefull, a real gem.  avoid guides of the sites . Prefer a guide of Cuernavaca if you can. you will find them in Cuernavaca downtown calle Ruiz de Alarcon close to a french restaurant.  The access to the site can be difficult if you don\'t have a car.

address.streetAddress: Carretera Federal Xochicalco Tetlama, sin numero Xochicalco, Municipio de Miacatlan, Morelos

127639911.name: Great ruins--make sure to see the Observatorio!
127639911.author: a TripAdvisor user
127639911.reviewBody: It was fun to visit these ruins--they are quite impressive and are located up on a hill with nice views of the surrounding areas. Make sure to check out the Observatorio--it was definitely the coolest part, but it\'s not located around the back of the ruins so you have to keep your eye out for signs.

address.streetAddress: Carretera Federal Xochicalco Tetlama, sin numero Xochicalco, Municipio de Miacatlan, Morelos

127088678.name: Relaxing ruins with wonderful vistas
127088678.author: a TripAdvisor user
127088678.reviewBody: The cave to the observatory was totally unique to all the ruins I have been to.  There is not the high temples but some wonderful carvings and the museum is 1st rate and the views to the lake and surrounding valley is wonderful.  The grounds have information in English but the museum does not but still well worth the time.

address.streetAddress: Carretera Federal Xochicalco Tetlama, sin numero Xochicalco, Municipio de Miacatlan, Morelos

126741238.name: Incredible historic spot to visit!
126741238.author: a TripAdvisor user
126741238.reviewBody: I visited this spot with Eric - a guide from Cuernavaca.  He was very informative and made the visit excellent.  It is very amazing how these pyramids were built and incredible to know that people lived as they did.  The museum is beautiful and so well preserved.  My only complaint was the signs in the museum where not in English as well as Spanish.  This is a great spot to visit and you should not miss it when visiting Cuernavaca.  \nStop for a Michelata on the roadside when travelling - they are so good!!!

address.streetAddress: Carretera Federal Xochicalco Tetlama, sin numero Xochicalco, Municipio de Miacatlan, Morelos

126502756.name: Fascinating site but must read Spanish
126502756.author: a TripAdvisor user
126502756.reviewBody: Other reviews have detailed this interesting and as yet only partially excavated archaeological attraction and museum.    Unfortunately, the signs and descriptions in\nthe well laid out and attractive museum were almost entirely in Spanish.  Unless you speak and read Spanish, you will get much more out of the site if you have an English speaking guide.  We were able to retain one called Carlos who picked us up and drove us to the site and well as taking us around both the museum and ruins for a very reasonable amount.   Without his assistance we would not have had such a positive experience.   Unlike sites like Stonehenge, you can get right up and touch these ruins.

address.streetAddress: Carretera Federal Xochicalco Tetlama, sin numero Xochicalco, Municipio de Miacatlan, Morelos

125439613.name: Xochicalco
125439613.author: a TripAdvisor user
125439613.reviewBody: Excellent historical site.  We had the extra treat of the university doing a ceremony while we were there, amazing!  Glad the observatory was open.

address.streetAddress: Carretera Federal Xochicalco Tetlama, sin numero Xochicalco, Municipio de Miacatlan, Morelos

124842875.name: Amazing experience.
124842875.author: a TripAdvisor user
124842875.reviewBody: Not as fabulous as many ruins in Mexico, and in need of some clean up of the trash.

address.streetAddress: Carretera Federal Xochicalco Tetlama, sin numero Xochicalco, Municipio de Miacatlan, Morelos

120740040.name: Xochicalco- Meeting of the Calendars!
120740040.author: a TripAdvisor user
120740040.reviewBody: Even if you have seen the Pyramids of the Sun and Moon, this is worth a visit.  The museum and the grounds are well maintained and another glimpse of past civilizations.

address.streetAddress: Carretera Federal Xochicalco Tetlama, sin numero Xochicalco, Municipio de Miacatlan, Morelos

120438893.name: A 360` spectacular view from these ancient pyramids
120438893.author: a TripAdvisor user
120438893.reviewBody: Only about 35 minutes outside of Cuernavaca are the restored ruins of Xochicalco. This ancient city brought groups of different  mini cultures together. Our guide Guillermo told us about the history of the people and the site. There is a beautiful museum close by that is part of the park. To use the phrase "valio la pena" it was truly worth the short drive to see Xochicalco.

address.streetAddress: Carretera Federal Xochicalco Tetlama, sin numero Xochicalco, Municipio de Miacatlan, Morelos

118701901.name: A must see while in Cuernavaca
118701901.author: a TripAdvisor user
118701901.reviewBody: You can either get a taxi or go by collectivo to save on transportation cost. \nEither way it\'s still inexpensive to get there and the entrance fee is cheap.\nSpend at least two hours here to see the museum and the site.

address.streetAddress: Carretera Federal Xochicalco Tetlama, sin numero Xochicalco, Municipio de Miacatlan, Morelos

100392041.name: Xochicalco, excellent place to visit
100392041.author: a TripAdvisor user
100392041.reviewBody:
I have personally been here about 10 times in the past 4 years.  Obviously I like it.  

This is the 4th most important place to visit of its nature following Chitzen Itza, Teotihuacan, and Palenque.

Hire a guide in front of the museum.  This will definitely be worth your investment.  Their narration about the place is a must to understand and enjoy.

Bring a sun hat and carry a bottle of water.  There are no bathrooms on the site but they are available in the museum and near the entrance gate to the remains.

address.streetAddress: Carretera Federal Xochicalco Tetlama, sin numero Xochicalco, Municipio de Miacatlan, Morelos

90956354.name: Magnificient and magical
90956354.author: a TripAdvisor user
90956354.reviewBody: Facinating must see.  I\'ve been to Palenque, Monte Alban and Tikal.  Xochicalco (pronounced Zo-she-call-ko) is like a boutique ruin. It\'s large but not so overwhelming you get lost.  Super neat thing!  They have historical signage in English.  Monte Alban and Tikal does not.  Also it\'s amazing how they reconstructed it and allow you to climb the ruins.  It was a very moving experience.  Take a water bottle.  We paid approximately $50 for a taxi ride and he was willing to wait three hours for us although it was not necessary.  We only spent 1.5 hours at the ruins.  \nI understand Friday and Saturday there is a light show but it didn\'t sound like my style.

address.streetAddress: Carretera Federal Xochicalco Tetlama, sin numero Xochicalco, Municipio de Miacatlan, Morelos

73220246.name: Extremely well put together large scale...
73220246.author: a TripAdvisor user
73220246.reviewBody: Extremely well put together large scale pyramid area about an hour from cuernavaca. Catch a bus from town to miacatlan or el rodeo then pick up a taxi to the museum entrance. The site is on top of a hill and has spectacular 360 degree views. There is plenty of information in Spanish and English or you could hire a guide for the site in the museum.

address.streetAddress: Carretera Federal Xochicalco Tetlama, sin numero Xochicalco, Municipio de Miacatlan, Morelos

56773071.name: Wow!
56773071.author: a TripAdvisor user
56773071.reviewBody: Our visit to Xochicalco was one of the highlights of our recent trip to Central Mexico. The site and the nearby Museum are both fascinating. The site is large, accessible, and not at all crowded with visitors. You can easily spen several hours wandering around the extensive grounds. Our only disappointment was that the astronomy cave was not open on the day we were there. This site is really worth the trip. The nearby site of Coatetelco is much smaller but also worth a stop.

address.streetAddress: Carretera Federal Xochicalco Tetlama, sin numero Xochicalco, Municipio de Miacatlan, Morelos

51102308.name: Great Site - low crowds
51102308.author: a TripAdvisor user
51102308.reviewBody: This is a beautiful site which is not too far from the highway.  The museum has wonderful artifacts with easy to understand explanations.  We hardly saw any other people so it really felt like we had the place to ourselves.

address.streetAddress: Carretera Federal Xochicalco Tetlama, sin numero Xochicalco, Municipio de Miacatlan, Morelos

47579495.name: Fabulous - not be be missed!
47579495.author: a TripAdvisor user
47579495.reviewBody:
We visited this site in 2007 as a shore excursion from our cruise ship which docked in Acapulco.  We had some concerns about the length of the tour, since it was a 3.5 hour van ride to get there (and another 3.5 hour ride back to Acapulco). Once we arrived, we knew it was well worth it.  Only about 1/3 of this site has been excavated, but what a magnificent place it is!  Our docent guided us around all the structures and had so much information it was almost too much to absorb in a single afternoon.  This place is where various Mesoamerican  cultures converged and met, so there are a lot of different cultural influences in the architecture and carvings.  A man in our tour group who had visited other other Mexican archeological sites stated that this site was better than all the other sites combined.

Wear walking shoes - there are some slight inclines and steps but otherwise it is easy to negotiate.  However, it is not appropriate for wheelchairs, walkers etc.  The weather is pleasant as this site is located in the mountains, and the blistering heat of the lowlands is not to be found here.

Given the opportunity, I would definitely visit this place again.

address.streetAddress: Carretera Federal Xochicalco Tetlama, sin numero Xochicalco, Municipio de Miacatlan, Morelos

35699101.name: A MUST-DO if you\'re in Cuernavaca
35699101.author: a TripAdvisor user
35699101.reviewBody: Visited this pyramid complex and museum, in fact so much that I\'m going back again in 2 months.  You can tour on your own leisurely, recommend highly that you buy one of the maps in the store by the exit.  Just backtrack from the entrance, and go around to the exit and there\'s the store - outside the complex gate.  We\'re on a budget, so instead of taking a $600 peso personal taxi who\'d wait for me, I did the adventure approach and took a 1st class bus to the Xochicalco de Cruz (crossroads), and waited 5 min for a taxi to come by, Overpaid him $50 pesos, then after touring the site waited for the low end city bus to bring me back to Cuernavaca.  Whole trip cost me less than $100 pesos (about $8.50 US).  But know some spanish.  Back to the site...really liked it, one of the better small pyramid sites I\'ve been to, very interesting complex of buildings and ball court.  Very close to Cuernavaca, it\'s a must do!

address.streetAddress: Carretera Federal Xochicalco Tetlama, sin numero Xochicalco, Municipio de Miacatlan, Morelos

5474633.name: Xochicalco......So cool
5474633.author: a TripAdvisor user
5474633.reviewBody:
I loved my visit to Xochicalco.  LIke the other post, make sure that you bring some water because it can be very warm and there isn't much shade.  The cost is about 40 pesos ($4 US)
The coolest part was the observatory, at a certain time of day a thin beam of light shines in a very dark room, very cool looking.  
The pyramids are all decent sized, not nearly as big as teotihuacan, but very cool nonetheless.  They also have a nice air conditioned museum that is a nice attraction as well.  If you are visiting Cuernavaca for a few days, a visit to Xochicalco is a must.

address.streetAddress: Carretera Federal Xochicalco Tetlama, sin numero Xochicalco, Municipio de Miacatlan, Morelos

2269588.name: Natural Observatory
2269588.author: a TripAdvisor user
2269588.reviewBody:
Despite the horrific, dry heat the Archaeological Zone of Xochicalco is as impressive as the Aztec Tehutihucan. It is resplendent with its Observatorio used during the Summer Soltice and is found inside a cave. On the grounds surroundng are the court of the Juego de Pelota (a form of early basketball), the steam room used to purify the winners of the game before their sacrifice to the gods, the cistern, and the area in which the cremated ashes of the winners are placed before they are carried away by the Wind God. 

The tour is to be undertaken only by those physically capable of walking and climbing many sets of vertically challenging steps. The trip is a unique study into Mesoamerican Indian history and is well worth your time. Bring bottled water and a good hat and sunblock for protection against the unrelenting sun. It is only about 45 minutes from Cuernavaca by bus. Unforgetable and wonderful.

address.streetAddress: Carretera Federal Xochicalco Tetlama, sin numero Xochicalco, Municipio de Miacatlan, Morelos

649037945.name: Focus on Mexican Culture NOT just Spanish
649037945.author: a TripAdvisor user
649037945.reviewBody: Total experience from being picked up at the Mexico City Airport, daily Spanish Lessons (Tailored for my level) and Mexico City, Xochicalco, Tazco, and Tepoztl\u00e1n. Additionally, ASLI arranged for boarding with a local Mexican Family to enhance immersion skills. \nVery student oriented with knowledgeable educators and caring admin staff.  Would heartily recommend an extended stay or a short stay to enhance your Spanish Skills.

address.streetAddress: Privada Prado San Jeronimo 8 Colonia la Pradera

607187880.name: Amazing 2 weeks with family
607187880.author: a TripAdvisor user
607187880.reviewBody: What a great visit to Cuernavaca with my family. I spent 2 weeks with my 3 kids (ages 18, 15 and 10) learning Spanish for 3 hrs every morning. I was so nervous that my kids would protest taking Spanish lessons over their vacation but they loved it! The teachers were wonderful and we all learned so much. In fact, they all want to continue via Skype! So sad that our vacation is over. Can\u2019t wait to come back.

address.streetAddress: Privada Prado San Jeronimo 8 Colonia la Pradera

598885164.name: Excellent Immersion Experience
598885164.author: a TripAdvisor user
598885164.reviewBody:
I studied Spanish at ASLI for 3 weeks this summer because I wanted to improve my Spanish speaking skills and understanding of Mexican history and culture. As a teacher, this is important to my work because so many of my students and their families speak Spanish and are originally from Mexico.

Before I traveled to Mexico, I had taken some Spanish classes as an adult, but had not improved nearly as much as I hoped. Because most classes occurred once or twice per week, it was hard to retain and practice what I was learning. In contrast, from the moment I arrived in Cuernavaca until the moment I departed, I was astounded by the amount of personalized attention and practice with Spanish I received. I was able to study Spanish grammar, conversation, and culture in small classes of between two and five students, for six hours each day. Additionally, I practiced Spanish with my host family, with museum guides, and even with taxi drivers! Everyone I met in Mexico was so willing to help me practice and improve, and I noticed how much this continuous practice contributed to my learning. 

My other objective in visiting Mexico was to improve my understanding of Mexican history and culture, since so many of my students and their families are originally from Mexico. As with my language studies, my experiences in Mexico far exceeded my expectations. I visited cultural sites, public and private schools, and many museums. Through these experiences, I deepened my understanding of the many and varied histories of the people of Mexico, and left  with new questions and directions for further study. Additionally, having the chance to live with a Mexican family for three weeks enhanced my understanding of the beautiful local culture in Cuernavaca.

As I look forward to this fall and years to come, I feel confident that having taken this trip will change my teaching practice for the better. I am excited to continue practicing the Spanish I have learned, and to use it to improve my communication and relationships with students’ families.

address.streetAddress: Privada Prado San Jeronimo 8 Colonia la Pradera

559271697.name: Exceeded my expectations!
559271697.author: a TripAdvisor user
559271697.reviewBody: From my first contact with the school via email to the hugs at the end of my two week stay, the staff and teachers at the school went beyond what was expected to make my stay a positive one.   I had a problem with my I phone and needed a new cable....cable purchased and tech situation fixed (all by a staff member).  The staff helped setting up weekend adventures. I was provided with a loving, caring, and comfortable experience with a host family a few blocks from the school.   The two teachers I had were both very experienced teachers.  I did happen to be there at a time when there were very few students.... making my experience an intimate one.

address.streetAddress: Privada Prado San Jeronimo 8 Colonia la Pradera

542525532.name: I love learning Spanish at the Spanish Language Institute!!!!
542525532.author: a TripAdvisor user
542525532.reviewBody:
My husband and I have taken Spanish classes for 2 weeks all over Latin America in the past 10 years, because it is one of our favorite types of vacations. Also, we usually have stayed with families. Five years ago we decided to study Spanish at the Spanish Language Institute because of a reference given to us by a previous student. After having studied Spanish in schools in Oaxaca and Morelia Mexico, Antigua Guaemala and Cuenca Ecuador, we decided to study in Cuernavaca. It was love at first site with the friendly family, the excellent teachers and the fun activities. 

I finally broke through and could understand the subjunctive explained well, so that I could finally understand it. After our classes here 5 years ago we decided to have weekly lesson via Skype with the school. Since we both work, it was the only way we could continue to learn with the excellent teachers that give so much! This year we finally returned to study at the school and love it just as much as before. The school is so accommodating, that any concern is resolved and the experience is so positive and enjoyable. My husband and I can highly recommend every teacher that we have had at the school. I wish I had more vacation time to study with immersion. I plan to possibly become an interpreter some day because the school teaches all levels, up to the highest level. 
The family that we stayed with was so kind and the food was excellent and plentiful. The accommodations were clean and quiet. We walked to school in 15 minutes and felt safe the entire time. Thank you Maru, Paco, Edgar and Rosita in the office for all you do to help students have a great experience with overall with planning and excursions. Thank you profesoras Susana and Arminda for the best help learning Spanish and correcting errors. Thank you Angelina and Rafael, one of the best families for comfort and additional help with conversation during meals. We will return!

address.streetAddress: Privada Prado San Jeronimo 8 Colonia la Pradera

536753901.name: Very responsive and professional
536753901.author: a TripAdvisor user
536753901.reviewBody: My son is taking a gap year during high school to immerse himself in a bit of Spanish language and culture and the folks at ASLI have been extremely accommodating in creating a custom course for him. He really likes his teachers and the homestays are with very nice, Spanish-speaking families.

address.streetAddress: Privada Prado San Jeronimo 8 Colonia la Pradera

523297379.name: The best place to learn Spanish in Cuernavaca
523297379.author: a TripAdvisor user
523297379.reviewBody: I am so pleased with my choice to attend ASLI in Cuernavaca.  The school staff is amazing. I have just completed one week (of two) and my maestros (Paquita Y Susanna) were the best Spanish instructors that I have ever had.  We spent the mornings learning grammar, and the afternoons practicing what we learned.  The entire staff is wonderful and so helpful.  They have organized very interesting excursions for us, which included a cooking class and a guided tour to Xochicalco - both were EXCELLENT.  I am not staying with a Mexican family on this trip, but my classmates are very pleased with their experience.  I will definitely return for more classes and stay with a family next time.

address.streetAddress: Privada Prado San Jeronimo 8 Colonia la Pradera

511113511.name: Not just a day program - Teens (a week or more)
511113511.author: a TripAdvisor user
511113511.reviewBody: We took 5 grandchildren (young teens) for 9 days, and we all had a great experience.  The teens stayed with Mexican families, and my husband and I in an apartment.  The kids were all warmly welcomed, and became part of their families for our time there.  They had Spanish classes all morning, tailored to their proficiency levels, and in the afternoons made field trips, as well as on the weekends, which we were invited to attend.  They loved Teotihuacan, las Estacas and other adventures.  The Institute gave its students a fiesta complete with pi\u00f1ata, dancing and mariachis, and also salsa lessons.  Congratulations, Maru and staff, for a beautifully run program.

address.streetAddress: Privada Prado San Jeronimo 8 Colonia la Pradera

493148268.name: Everything you need to learn...
493148268.author: a TripAdvisor user
493148268.reviewBody:
not only Spanish, but about the history and culture of México is here at ASLI.  Yes, I've written reviews before, but I just returned from ANOTHER unforgettable trip with a small group of high school students and adults at varying beginner-to-intermediate-to-advanced levels.  All were comfortable; all were welcomed and perfectly placed in wonderful host families.  You can come to ASLI alone, with a friend or partner, or with a group.  I have done all three! 

From the moment we were greeted at the airport, we had an incredible time! For the teens, three hours of classes a day were perfect.  We had planned excursions in the afternoons to el centro, pyramids, historical sites, museums, and more, from both ancient and ultra-modern México. Maru, Edgar, Rosita, Paco, and all of the teachers are experienced, understanding, and ready to answer any questions.  The side trips, tours, and other places in the city they can recommend will personalize your experience.  We climbed Teotihuacan, took salsa lessons with Amore Salsa, visited the Robert Brady Museum, the Cathedral of Cuernavaca, Xochicalco, Tepotzlán (via una ruta, thanks to Maru!) Vista Hermosa, and the Shrine of Our Lady of Guadalupe.  My students really enjoyed the VIP cinema on our last night of classes, and Las Estacas natural waterpark on the day before we left.

The school is in an area that is within walking distance to everything you need for a great trip, including tacos at La Gringa III, Italian Coffee, and pizza or pasta at Armando's or Marco Polo, if you're not sharing comida with your family.  If you're not into walking much, the Radio Taxis are safe, prompt, and inexpensive. 

Spanish Language Institute is the BEST choice for a learning experience, plus more.....you'll come away with improved Spanish, a love for Cuernavaca, and a promise to yourself to return.  "Nunca,  Adiós.  Siempre,  Hasta la vista."

address.streetAddress: Privada Prado San Jeronimo 8 Colonia la Pradera

487988888.name: Wonderful experience!
487988888.author: a TripAdvisor user
487988888.reviewBody:
I learned about this wonderful school from TripAdvisor about 4 months ago while setting up a vacation with my friend to see her relatives in Cuernavaca and Mexico City. At that time I'd been working on my Spanish for about a year but my progress was a bit slow.  (My goal is to someday be fluent so that I can use in my work at court and for travel...)In February I started Skype classes through this school with Marie who is an excellent instructor.  I then attended one week during my 10 day trip to Mexico. I  participated in the semi-private program (which ended up being private with Tere for three hours a day because I was the only student!), in addition to 2 1/2 hours of group classes with only three other students. For the group classes I was appropriately matched with some nursing students and we focused on health terminology which for me is very useful...
Even though it was only a week this experience really helped improve my conversation skills and gave me more confidence.  The teachers are excellent and the directors of the school, Maru and Paco, are incredibly kind and helpful with advice on local customs and safe travel tips.

Muchas Gracias to Maru, Paco and teachers Marie, Tere, and Arminda!!! I will be back soon for another session.  Very grateful to have participated in your wonderful program😊

address.streetAddress: Privada Prado San Jeronimo 8 Colonia la Pradera

655085004.name: Still closed and incorrect address
655085004.author: a TripAdvisor user
655085004.reviewBody: The gardens have been closed for reparations since the last earthquake but expect to be open again in March 2019.  Check before going.  Then note that address has been confused.  Matamoros, mentioned in the TripAdvisor by listing,  is in the Centro; in fact, the Jardin and museo are located on Mariano Matamoros in a nearby suburban neighborhood of Acapatzingo.

itemReviewed.name: Jardin Botanico y Museo de Medicina Tradicional y Herbolaria

545796311.name: Average Garden
545796311.author: a TripAdvisor user
545796311.reviewBody: Lovely garden but could be well maintained. It\'s nice and peaceful and has a lot of history. Lovely place to take a walk.

itemReviewed.name: Jardin Botanico y Museo de Medicina Tradicional y Herbolaria

511162865.name: Children\'s program is excellent
511162865.author: a TripAdvisor user
511162865.reviewBody: My children recently attended a two week long day camp at this park and it was well run, educational and a lot of fun. The program has been running for years every summer, it is free to attend though you must bring art supplies. \n\nThe park itself is gorgeous, so peaceful and beautiful. I love the history of the buildings and my kids especially loved all the turtles in the swimming pool. We will definitely be back for camp next year!

itemReviewed.name: Jardin Botanico y Museo de Medicina Tradicional y Herbolaria

476491306.name: Where is it??
476491306.author: a TripAdvisor user
476491306.reviewBody: The address given on TripAdvisor Matamoros 14 is wrong. I know because I just wasted 40 minutes in uber in a vain attempt to find it. There\'s nothing approaching a Botanical Garden at that address. Everyone the driver asked looked at us as if we were crazy. The driver knew a garden on Morelos near the Zocalo. We went and it was closed. (Noon on Monday.) We gave up and returned to the Zocalo. 40 minutes plus uber fare wasted!

itemReviewed.name: Jardin Botanico y Museo de Medicina Tradicional y Herbolaria

467681948.name: Botanical garden
467681948.author: a TripAdvisor user
467681948.reviewBody: While this is not a large garden, it does have a good selection of many of the tropical plants of this area.  You can see adult specimens of several trees and palms.  Certainly worth a visit.

itemReviewed.name: Jardin Botanico y Museo de Medicina Tradicional y Herbolaria

461539673.name: nice afternoon in a wonderful park like and quiet setting
461539673.author: a TripAdvisor user
461539673.reviewBody: I would have given this site a five except that many garden plots were empty.  I felt that I could have learned more about the buildings and effectiveness of the medicines as well as how to make them from the plants.

itemReviewed.name: Jardin Botanico y Museo de Medicina Tradicional y Herbolaria

459770465.name: Chill
459770465.author: a TripAdvisor user
459770465.reviewBody: It is not as big as I thought, but the visit is really enjoyable. The traditional architecture and vegetation coexist very nicely. Information is not as specific as I imagined, however it is enough to catch a glimpse of central features. It is refreshing for a typical hot day in Cuernavaca. If you enjoy plants, don\'t skip.

itemReviewed.name: Jardin Botanico y Museo de Medicina Tradicional y Herbolaria

360983754.name: A very calming and peaceful garden and small museum
360983754.author: a TripAdvisor user
360983754.reviewBody: This is the place for me as I use herbal remedies and love to explore the natural medicines used worldwide. The garden area was very interesting and had a very quiet and peaceful atmosphere. The museum has displays of different herbs and some old photos as well as herbs used as art. I would love to visit this area again next time I\'m in Cuernavaca.

itemReviewed.name: Jardin Botanico y Museo de Medicina Tradicional y Herbolaria

349726479.name: La Casa Chica
349726479.author: a TripAdvisor user
349726479.reviewBody: While the Spanish name literally means "the little house" this name is idiomatic for "the mistress\'s house." Emperor Maximiliano built this for La India Bonita, daughter of his gardener at the Jardin Borda downtown. The original house is now a museum of traditional medicine; it used to include peyote, but I think someone stole it. The swimming pool has fish and frogs, but they\'re hard to see in the green water. The botanical gardens are very attractive and interesting, although all the signs are in Spanish. They frequently have workshops and lectures on traditional medicine. You can also visit an 18th century church across the street.

itemReviewed.name: Jardin Botanico y Museo de Medicina Tradicional y Herbolaria

349502580.name: Lots of interesting plants!
349502580.author: a TripAdvisor user
349502580.reviewBody: We went with friends and spent a few hours wandering around, looking at the variety of plants and just enjoying the huge grounds. There were so many plants to admire and some ideas to try in our gardens when we get home.  \n\nWe were almost the only people there - not sure why - maybe off season or the time of day. But having it to ourselves was nice.  Note admission was free so it really is worth the time if you are interested in things botanical and want to see some nature in the middle of a large city.

itemReviewed.name: Jardin Botanico y Museo de Medicina Tradicional y Herbolaria

641366273.name: Lots of street food
641366273.author: a TripAdvisor user
641366273.reviewBody: The beautiful gazebo is hardly noticed with all the food wagons and shoe shine men. At night there are musicians playing.

639944015.name: Corrected misleading information
639944015.author: a TripAdvisor user
639944015.reviewBody: As an American resident of Cuernavaca, the first thing I did was to correct the Google map location. The second is to note that Cuernavaca has two main squares, collectively called the "Zocolo." The larger is the "Plaza de la Constitucion" located between the "Palacio de Cortes" and the "Palacio de Gobernacion" which is an office building for the state government. The "Morelotes" statue is located here. The smaller "Jardin Juarez" is north of the "Palacio de Gobernacion" and includes the famous kiosk designed by Gustav Eiffel.\nThe "Plaza de la Constitucion" is large and open, surrounded by benches relaxing. Families like to spend time here, especially on Sundays. Sometimes there are political demonstrations, sometimes there are special exhibits (food, handicrafts, books, etc.), and often there are clowns or jugglers.\nThere are numerous open-air cafes, fast food restaurants, and shops around the Plaza. It\'s the best place to purchase souvenirs, and no visitor should miss it.

617234420.name: Cuernavaca city center, the Zocalo and surroundings.
617234420.author: a TripAdvisor user
617234420.reviewBody: There are many interesting things to see and do within walking distance, great cafes and restaurants, Casa Spencer and Brady Museums, the Cortez Palace, the Cathedral and the Borda Gardens, it\'s well worth the trip to colonial Cuernavaca.

579347317.name: Great place to see and experience the culture
579347317.author: a TripAdvisor user
579347317.reviewBody: This is the place to be everyday. There\u2019s many things to see and many things buy, to eat, to experience. It\u2019s very popular place for people to meet, to gather, to have fun or shop together. The foods are so good. There\u2019s all sorts of shopping nearby. Many different shows to watch for free. You get to see and experience the Mexican culture here. It\u2019s very safe and you\u2019ll love this area. It\u2019s stretches 5-6 blocks and it\u2019s great for couple, friends, family, kids. It\u2019s a must visit and you\u2019ll enjoy this plaza.

557165872.name: Walking at night was very pleasant
557165872.author: a TripAdvisor user
557165872.reviewBody: Many people with their families. Different options to eat and drink like "Esquimos" like a natural flavored frappe

551351728.name: Nice zocalo
551351728.author: a TripAdvisor user
551351728.reviewBody: The Plaza was always busy, more so on the weekend. Musical groups delighted crowds and many people appeared to come here to relax for a while.

550925807.name: Very picturesque
550925807.author: a TripAdvisor user
550925807.reviewBody: This is located in the Zocalo of Cuernavaca surrounded by colorful street vendors. Nice to walk around and take pictures

501653889.name: Nice w
501653889.author: a TripAdvisor user
501653889.reviewBody: Nice area. The gardens with all the trees and flowers was very nice. A relaxing area. It was so clean. Lots of restaurents around.

497207622.name: A pretty gathering place
497207622.author: a TripAdvisor user
497207622.reviewBody: It is a park surrounded by benches with a gazebo in the middle. The point of interest is that is was designed by Mr. Eiffel, of Eiffel tower fame.

474271195.name: Lovely Zocalo
474271195.author: a TripAdvisor user
474271195.reviewBody: I suspect most of the locals know this place as the Zocalo. It is a beautiful square with plenty of people to interact with. Artisans sell their work right there. If you would like to see a real Mexican city, come here and spend some time observing.

467653608.name: Eifel in Cuernavaca?
467653608.author: a TripAdvisor user
467653608.reviewBody: Yes! The kiosco of the PLaza de la Constituci\u00f3n was designed by Mr. Eifel. If you want to know more about this, visit the Plaza and taste a Esquites adiring the kiosko.

467618938.name: Just one of many charming
467618938.author: a TripAdvisor user
467618938.reviewBody: locations in this authentic Mexican city.  It is not your typical tourist trap.  This is what I fondly call the REAL Mexico!  Families stroll and it is like a step back in time.

455688803.name: Lovely town center
455688803.author: a TripAdvisor user
455688803.reviewBody: Simply amazing, especially love Saturday evenings with all the old folk dancing. Just have a seat and watch the people of Cuernavaca enjoy their day. Everyone is so happy, families are together enjoying life. The gazebo was built by Eifel and is absolutely gorgeous and has fruit drink vendors around its base and a band stand for entertainment. We are in love with Centro, Cuernavaca

445026157.name: This is a very typical place to look around and take pictures.
445026157.author: a TripAdvisor user
445026157.reviewBody: This is a very typical place to look around and take pictures. You can get an approach to the local culture and ambience  in this place. When we visited there was music. Very nice.

443099146.name: worthwhile
443099146.author: a TripAdvisor user
443099146.reviewBody: very nice place to look around and to hang out, and if you want to learn about the area, get your shoes shined here from one of the colorful boleros, who if you\'re lucky will regale you with some tales

430760628.name: People watch and enjoy.
430760628.author: a TripAdvisor user
430760628.reviewBody: This pocket of activity was a magnet in the busy surrounds.  Filled with vendors in a good way, children playing, plenty of benches, and great affordable snacks and juices at the base of the bandstand, it is a photographr-of-life\'s dream come true.  Joy abounds in the density of Centro!

351707340.name: Interesting place to people watch
351707340.author: a TripAdvisor user
351707340.reviewBody: This is an interesting place to people watch.  Really starts ginning on Friday and Saturday nights.  Lots of vendors, some performers, food, etc.  When I was in the center of the city, I usually made it a point to walk through this just to feel the vibes of the city.  Other than the people and the vendors, nothing else.  It is located in the center of the city

332249107.name: Busy place
332249107.author: a TripAdvisor user
332249107.reviewBody: We pass this square repeatedly throughout the day and there are lots of people relaxing or selling. There are some concerts in the beautiful gazebo at times. We preferred the larger square adjacent to this and enjoyed a lady who made and sold fresh churro so.

305838211.name: A taste of Mexican Cuerna Downtown :D
305838211.author: a TripAdvisor user
305838211.reviewBody: This is as colorful as it is becoming!  If something is happening, it is right here: you get to see people left and right, your shoes polished, cotton candy in many colors, and the fruit stand to enjoy smoothies, juices and blendies, you are going to like it if you enjoy the view of old Cuerna.\n\nThere is a lot of traffic in that area, but you can enjoy downtown by foot and you will! :D

301578170.name: Kiosk designed by Alexandre Gustave Eiffel (Eiffel Tower of Paris fame), shipped from England in the late 19th Century!
301578170.author: a TripAdvisor user
301578170.reviewBody: Great Plaza for sitting, enjoying the fresh tropical fruit stands, having shoes polished, listening to the vendor\'s calls for ballons, toys,and cookies, tasting the many traditional corn offerings such as esquites and enjoying the Thursday\'s performances of musicians playing marimba music.  Unfortunately, Tripadvisor\'s title for this Plaza is incorrect as too the address.  This Plaza is in the Centro Historico of Cuernavaca.

300700100.name: A true Mexican experience
300700100.author: a TripAdvisor user
300700100.reviewBody: Do you really want to enjoy and experience Mexican culture go here they play traditional music which I find very romantic and soothing they serve you wonderful food and its a fun afternoon

268126542.name: My favorite thing to do in Cuernavaca
268126542.author: a TripAdvisor user
268126542.reviewBody: Everyone in Cuernavaca just calls this plaza "el z\u00f3calo." It\'s the heart of downtown Cuernavaca, the best place to people watch and get a sense of the place.  There are sidewalk caf\u00e9s here, my favorite is Los Arcos. Lots of vendors selling their wares. Kids playing, people on benches reading the paper, people selling balloons and snacks from carts.  There\'s usually some kind of music in the afternoons. A couple of times a week people come to dance "danz\u00f3n," the mariachis hang out here and if you\'re lucky you\'ll hear them playing, a few times a week they have indigenous folk dances. My friends who live in Cuernavaca never go to the z\u00f3calo, they don\'t see the charm of it, but I really like it. It\'s busy and bustling most of the time, traffic in the downtown area can be bad, but you can\'t beat the spot for people watching. It is adjacent to another smaller square (where you see the gazebo). If there is some kind of political protest going on, it\'s likely to happen here, but I have never felt in danger or been worried about violence. For the most part, the protests are peaceful sit-ins, and the people protesting are happy to explain why they\'re protesting - you can get a lesson in current events if you speak Spanish and want to talk to them. My favorite thing to do in the mid-morning hours is buy a newspaper, sit at the cafe, read it while I have coffee, then stroll around and enjoy the sights. The Palace of Hernan Cort\u00e9s faces the zocalo at one end, the government building is at the other end, and all around are restaurants and shops. If you don\'t want to sit in a cafe, there are plenty of benches in the square. You can people watch for free.

219780973.name: El Kiosko
219780973.author: a TripAdvisor user
219780973.reviewBody: Being a natural from Cuernavaca, i can recall many stories that have happened to me right at this plaza. Or el kiosko like we usually call it. I remember Family sundays when we will stop in order to buy the paper and a fresh guava, Orange, mamey juice. You Think you know tropical fruits Think again, you will find some fruits you are most likely never seen before. I have. :) i remember buying balloons when they looked completly different from now a days ballons. They used to look like octopuses. I also have stoped by to buy corn, or ma\u00efs, with mayo, and chilly. Delicious. Or any of the street food they sell. I have collected bubbles makers, magazines, i have run behind the pigeons and fallen on the ground. Sometimes cleaner, sometimes dirtier. It reminds how much the City has changed and how badly it was treated during some periods in time. However it just feels like everything will be OK sitting right there on a bench. Listening to the Music, watching people dance. Under this beautiful French kiosk sent all the way from Par\u00eds, to our little town and our little square. If you can concentrate on the magic behind, you will love this place.

183750974.name: Lively zocalo, unusual gazebo, haunting birds
183750974.author: a TripAdvisor user
183750974.reviewBody:
What a great zocalo! (Two zocalos, actually.) 

Throngs of people of all ages. Vendors, jugglers, musicians, fire-eaters, little kids bouncing huge inflatable "pencils" off the crowded paving stones. Statues. Seniors gingerly dancing to an old song; break-dancers with "Brooklyn" t-shirts. Elote-sellers trying to outdo each other with their pitches.

The elegant gazebo is fantastic, elevated about 15' up, with shops below-grade level underneath. What a great concept. When I was there, a battle of the "La Banda" bands was underway. Local tuba players and visiting trumpeters vied for attention in a great, brassy clash.

At sunset, hundreds of birds descend on one tree overlooking the zocalo. What a surreal sound and sight. Check it out.

Sit in the zocalo for awhile or grab an icy cold beverage at one of the restaurants surrounding the zocalos. A sweet scene.

141872684.name: A little dirty
141872684.author: a TripAdvisor user
141872684.reviewBody: We went in the afternoon for a walk and felt a little disappointed as it was dirty and not very well kept. There was people smoking dope in plain sight and it smelt of rubbish.\n\nIt could be a fantastic place with a litttle TLC.

127013234.name: Eiffel\'s Handprint in Mexico
127013234.author: a TripAdvisor user
127013234.reviewBody: The Plaza de la Constutution isn\'t particularly exceptional for any reason other than it\'s star centerpiece, the gazebo designed by Gustave Eiffel. I was actually surprised and delighted to stumble upon the construction so many miles away from Paris. The fin de si\u00e8cle architecture of the gazebo/band stand, elevated above the plaza gives this small square most, if not all, of its charm. The fruit and juice stands below it offer some most needed refreshment on a hot day. As it is a relatively small area just off the central plaza and next to the government buildings, it doesn\'t take much of a crowd to fill it up. Nonetheless, after my visit to the Palacio de Cortes across the square, it was the perfect location to find a bench, enjoy a cup of mango and papaya, watch the ballon sellers, while, at the same time, relax in the glow of another beautiful Eiffel creation. For more on my travels to Cuernacaca and DF, check out my travel blog at http://searchingfordiego.blogspot.com.

22531783.name: Two Plazas next door to each other
22531783.author: a TripAdvisor user
22531783.reviewBody: Cuernavaca actually has two main plazas that are right next to each other and in the center of town. They are surrounded by government buildings, the Cortes Palace, restaurants, and more. They always seemed crowded with locals and food and drink stands but did not strike us as nice as those in other cities in Mexico. And the birds that swarmed into the trees at sunset were more noisy and messy than attractive. We did walk through these two squares more because they were the walkways from one place to another than a place to relax.

637306761.name: Exciting show
637306761.author: a TripAdvisor user
637306761.reviewBody: The cultural center has recently been remodeled, and there are several theaters for different sized events. We saw the light show about the pyramids twice.

596537696.name: Great concert hall
596537696.author: a TripAdvisor user
596537696.reviewBody: This place really surpassed any expectation. The location is privileged, just in front of the Teopanzolco pyramid. The architecture is really world class. The interior covered in wood has an amazing acoustic.

580934941.name: Love it.
580934941.author: a TripAdvisor user
580934941.reviewBody: A peaceful space to relax and meditate.  I\u00b4ve been there several times with friends, although, the hours are flaky to the public and since it is a facility operated by the local government you might find it open or not regardless of their published hours.  Great to talk, to meditate and to have a quiet time, don\u00b4t miss it.

551222147.name: Video Mapping on Teopanzolco Pyramid
551222147.author: a TripAdvisor user
551222147.reviewBody: The video projection on the pyramid tells the story of this part of what is now Cuernavaca. The small village it was up to the important ceremonial center it became. It is a beautiful presentation  and is presented on Friday and Saturday evenings at 7 p.m.\nCuernavaca is one of two state capitals in Mexico with a Mesoamerican ceremonial center in it. The other city is Mexico City with the Aztec Temple (Templo Mayor).

651488443.name: Nice ruins (but still closed)
651488443.author: a TripAdvisor user
651488443.reviewBody: From the center we headed to check out the Teopanzolco archeological site, located outside of town. After a long walk, we reached the destination yet found out it was closed due to the earthquake which had hit the surrounding area just a few months before. So after admiring it from the outside we retraced our steps and headed into the old town.

address.streetAddress: Rio Balsas s/n, Teopanzolco Vista Hermosa Colonia Vista Hermosa

638451005.name: Hidden treasures
638451005.author: a TripAdvisor user
638451005.reviewBody: 2017 earthquake revealed another hidden pyramid under the main one, older than Plaza Mayor in Mexico City

address.streetAddress: Rio Balsas s/n, Teopanzolco Vista Hermosa Colonia Vista Hermosa

585787901.name: Closed for construction
585787901.author: a TripAdvisor user
585787901.reviewBody: We were excited to see this site, as we had yet to see any archaeological sites in Mexico so far, and this was right in town. We were really bummed to show up and see the gates locked. We thought you could still go inside despite it being under construction. It looks like a nearby building had folks on top viewing the site from a distance, but we did not want to unload all our kids from the car for just that.

address.streetAddress: Rio Balsas s/n, Teopanzolco Vista Hermosa Colonia Vista Hermosa

579115045.name: Would\u2019ve been good but was under construction
579115045.author: a TripAdvisor user
579115045.reviewBody: It was unfortunate I didn\u2019t get to enjoy this place. It was close for construction due to the earthquake. From the outside looking in I think I would\u2019ve enjoy this place. It was local in Cuernavaca so you don\u2019t have to travel far to see it. It was very well kept and clean. It\u2019s was pretty big having that it\u2019s in the city. It\u2019s great for family, friends, couple to visit.

address.streetAddress: Rio Balsas s/n, Teopanzolco Vista Hermosa Colonia Vista Hermosa

455709687.name: Worth the quick stop
455709687.author: a TripAdvisor user
455709687.reviewBody: Nice stop on our way out of Cuernavaca. Small archaeological site but still worth the half hour it takes to walk around and climb the temples. On street parking (no cost) and it was free entry on Sunday, so win-win.\n\nBe sure to buy some popsicles from the man out front if he\'s there.

address.streetAddress: Rio Balsas s/n, Teopanzolco Vista Hermosa Colonia Vista Hermosa

449846950.name: Hidden gem
449846950.author: a TripAdvisor user
449846950.reviewBody: A small but interesting site in the city of Cuernavaca. If you are in the area, it is a nice way to spend an hour.

address.streetAddress: Rio Balsas s/n, Teopanzolco Vista Hermosa Colonia Vista Hermosa

365131857.name: Peace, Serenity and Tranquility
365131857.author: a TripAdvisor user
365131857.reviewBody:
Cuernavaca is a bustling city today and after spending time in other parts of the city with it's traffic and noise, you need to take a breather by visiting the Sitio Arqueólogica Teopanzolco located in a quiet residential neighborhood of Vista Hermosa.

You will find the Sitio Arqueólogica Teopanzolco, (from the Nahuatl language meaning "the place of the old temple" in the Vista Hermosa Colonia on Rio Balsas just a few blocks from the intersection of Rio Mayo. While the area was once sprawling countryside of coniferous woodland with rolling hills, it now lies within the confines of this modern city. Most of the visible 15 remains, built on a hill formed by lava flowing from the nearby Popo Volcano, date from the Early Aztec period of 1150 to 1350.

Several of the reviews here are actually for Zona Arqueológica el Tepozteco, which is in Tepoztlan, Mexico. Perhaps because the title of the site given here on Trip Advisor is incorrect.

There are some taxi drivers who are not familiar with Cuernavaca, of course, so be sure before you get in to ask, "¿Sabe usted la forma de las pirámides de Teopanzolco?" before you get in the taxi. It is only a quick 10 minutes from downtown and the cost should not be more than 35 pesos. To arrive at the site, you only have to ask the taxi driver,

You should know that I am a bit jaded, as the Archeological Site of the Teopanzolco Pyramids is virtually in my backyard, as I live only a block and a half from them, and visit several times a week. It is part of my walking regimen and I enjoy siting in the shade in the quiet landscaped grounds and reading a book, while basking in the rich cultural history of Cuernavaca. What a shame that many visitors, which is apparent from the reviews here, that they define the historical importance of archeological sites by their size. Those with these expectations will never truly appreciate what they see in life. Teopanzolco provides a rich history of the Morelos Valley in which Cuernavaca sits. It was settled from about 2000 BC and there is evidence to believe that there was an earlier occupation in the great square of Teopanzolco.

During the Classic Period, Teopanzolco came under the influence of the great metropolis of Teotihuacan in the Valley of Mexico. By the Postclassic Period, various Nahua groups had moved in the Altiplano; the Tlahuicas Indians founded the city of Cuauhnahuac (the pre-Spanish name for Cuernavaca) pronounced Kwaa-nah-wok sometime around 1200 AD when they first settled here. They built the Teopanzolco Pyramids before being conquered by the Aztec emperor Moctezuma Ilhuicamina in 1427 AD. The once-peaceful Tlahuicas were integrated into the Aztec Empire and forced to pay tribute in large amounts of cotton clothing and blankets and to participate in the Aztec military campaigns. In 1521, with the arrival of the Spaniards, the prehispanic history of Teopanzolco was brought to a close.

It is believed that Teopanzolco was the original Ceremonial Center of the city of Cuauhnahuac during the Early Aztec period (AD 1150–1350) before the center was moved to a more defensible location, now the center of the modern city of Cuernavaca.

There are 15 structures within the park that were built between 1300 and 1521 and are of the Late Postclassic Period.

The most important and powerful structure is the central Great Platform. It was never finished and thus is the only pyramid to give present viewers the opportunity to see both the inner and outer structure and understand how the Aztec built their pyramids. The Ceremonial Center was dedicated (as was the Templo Mayor in Mexico City) to Huitzilopochtli (The God of the Sun, representing war and sacrifice) and Tlaloc (The God of Rain representing fertility and growth). 16th century Dominican Friar Diego Durán wrote, "These two gods were always meant to be together, since they were considered companions of equal power." Prior to the destruction of the Ceremonial Center, Great Platform supported two identical temples. On the north end was the Temple of Tlaloc and on the south was the Temple of Huitzilopochtli. The bases of the two temples are still intact. Tezcatlipoca, Ehecatl, among other Gods were worshiped at Teopanzolco.

When the Spaniards arrived in Cuauhnāhuac (renamed Cuernavaca by the Spaniards) and destroyed all symbols related to the past deities, the construction within the Ceremonial Center was stopped and the Ceremonial Center was covered over with dirt.

What you see is the Ceremonial Center of Teopanzolco, which is only a small part of the prehispanic City of Cuauhnāhuac, as most of the residential areas lie beneath the surrounding development. When the Spaniards arrived in Cuauhnāhuac (renamed Cuernavaca by the Spaniards) and destroyed all symbols related to the past deities, the construction within the Ceremonial Center was stopped and the Ceremonial Center was covered over with dirt.

The Ceremonial Center lay hidden until 1910, when during the Mexican Revolution, Emiliano Zapata's revolutionary forces installed cannons on top of the mound of dirt covering the Great Platform. When they begin firing shells into the federalist positions in the current center of Cuernavaca, the vibrations of the cannons shook loose the dirt and revealed the stonework below.

However, it was not until 1921 that the first excavations began. Further excavations by Mexican archaeologists Román Piña Chan and Eduardo Noguera took place in 1956 and 1957. Since 1985, the  Instituto Nacional de Antropología e Historia (INAH) is responsible for maintenance and minor excavations.

It is open from 9 a.m. to 5 p.m. and it is recommended that you visit in the mornings during the warmer months. There is a very small museum in the main entrance of the park and there are displays in English and Spanish to explain the site. The entry fee is $37 MXN (about $2 USD), but is free on Sundays and to seniors over 60 years of age at any time.

address.streetAddress: Rio Balsas s/n, Teopanzolco Vista Hermosa Colonia Vista Hermosa

361057844.name: Worth a short visit if you\'re in Cuernavaca
361057844.author: a TripAdvisor user
361057844.reviewBody: As another reviewer noted "It ain\'t Chichen Itza". Still, it\'s a small accessible ruin that\'s worth 30-45 minutes if you\'re a ruins aficionado. You can also skip it without feeling guilty.

address.streetAddress: Rio Balsas s/n, Teopanzolco Vista Hermosa Colonia Vista Hermosa

351589888.name: This Ain\'t Chichen Itza
351589888.author: a TripAdvisor user
351589888.reviewBody:
Cuernavaca is not filled with exceptional tourist sites, so on our last day we were going down the list to see what might be out there.  This small archaeological site gets a few positive mentions, so we thought we would give it a try.  It also gave us a chance to navigate on the buses using our modest Español.  We were able to find the right bus (perhaps) and it dropped us off about a half mile from Teopanzolco.
